summary: The European Airbus A380 flew The European Airbus A380 maiden test flight from France 10 years after design development started . The European Airbus A380 surpasses the Boeing 747 and breaks Airbus monopoly . Airlines worldwide have placed orders but airports may need modification to accommodate the weight and width of The European Airbus A380 . U.S. airlines have not placed an order . Airbus has fallen behind in production and a backlog of orders has developed . Airbus must sell at least 250 planes to break even financially . The European Airbus A380 is overweight and modifications to meet the weight requirements impacted the budget . Additional test flights are planned . Emirate Airlines ordered the first passenger A380 five months before the first passenger A380 December 2000 launch . In January Federal Express ordered the first cargo A380 . Thirteen non - American airlines have placed 154 orders ; China and Hong Kong have options . Commercial deliveries begin first quarter 2006 to Singapore . A380s will land at 25 airports worldwide , including New York , Los Angeles , San Francisco , Miami , Chicago , Dulles , Memphis and Anchorage . In February 2001 Airbus Hamburg plant expanded . Toulouse production started in January 2002 . In July 2003 Broughton , Wales got an Airbus plant . The first A380 arrived in January 2005 , taking its maiden test flight April 27 . The European Airbus A380 , took off on its maiden test flight on April 27 , 2005 in France . The European company , Airbus , is the newest competitor with Boeing . The European Airbus A380 is designed to carry 555 passengers , but can be expanded to 800 seats . Airbus stresses The European Airbus A380 fuel efficiency . its maiden test flight was successful . Orders for 149 aircraft from airlines and freight companies have been received . No US airline has ordered The European Airbus A380 yet . First commercial deliveries to Singapore are scheduled for 2006 . In 1994 Airbus began engineering The European Airbus A380 . Component production started in 2002 in Germany and France . A Toulouse assembly line opened in 2004 . Parts were pared down and new materials introduced to keep The European Airbus A380 at target weight but sent The European Airbus A380 over budget . The European Airbus A380 was unveiled in January 2005 and test flown in April . Airports need to make design changes to accommodate The European Airbus A380 . The US objects to government subsidies to Airbus and airport neighbors complain about noise .

summary: Airbus announced Airbus is two to six months behind Airbus promised A380 delivery schedule . Airlines are seeking millions in damages contractually agreed upon for delays . Airbus raised the price to approximately $ 292 million . A wing failure during testing may delay A380 safety certification . The U.S. is investigating whether A380 will need special safety regulations due to the turbulence A380 generates . 33 were injured in an emergency evacuation drill . 873 passengers and crew exited under 80 seconds and A380 passed testing . Airbus plans to deliver the first two jets to Singapore Airlines by the end of 2006 . By June 1 , 2005 customizing A380s for 15 different client requirements , notably for different passenger entertainment systems , had delayed deliveries up to 8 months , risking millions in penalties . The first A380 delivery ( to Singapore Airlines ) slid from early to late 2006 . With 159 orders from 16 customers and 100 options , production fell behind demand , raising the price to U.S. $ 292 million . Possible A380 air turbulence problems potentially requiring ICAO rule - making , a wing load test failure and passenger injuries during a simulated evacuation did not slow deliveries . By 2006 20 airports will be A380 - ready ; 38 by 2008 ; 60 by 2010 . A380 has passed A380 emergency evacuation test , an important component toward A380 official certification for commercial flights . Airbus executives say Airbus will have to pay millions in compensation for late deliveries of A380 . Production problems rather than safety or quality issues have caused late deliveries of the A380 . Airbus has 159 firm orders and 10 options from 16 customers . The U.S. is studying the potential for turbulence generated by A380 reflecting safety precautions . In 2005 A380 was six months behind schedule and owed millions in buyer compensation . Customized cabins and entertainment system installation problems caused delays . France called unreasonable a US - proposed safety review to determine whether A380 turbulence would require greater distances around A380 . Airbus raised A380 price by $ 10 million . A wing ruptured during a February 2006 stress test but A380 qualified in its emergency evacuation test , an important component toward the super jumbo 's official certification for commercial flights . Airbus was approaching Airbus break - even point of 250 plane sales . Twenty airports would be ready for A380s in 2006 , with Singapore Airlines being first to fly A380 .

summary: Ice continues to melt at an alarming rate in both the Arctic and Antarctic . Higher temperatures have shrunk the Arctic ice area 10 % and the Arctic ice area thickness 42 % in 30 years . The permafrost is shrinking , endangering infrastructure . These changes are threatening the culture and economy of the indigenous Artic population . Ice shelves in Antarctic are collapsing . The melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could raise ocean levels worldwide approximately 15 feet . Increased tourism in Antarctic is having an environmental impact . Researchers are debating whether greenhouse gases or natural climate cycles are the biggest cause of The melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet . Collapse of coastal Antarctic ice shelves accelerated eight - fold the seaward flow of inland glaciers , raising sea levels : Larsen A ( 1995 ) , Wilkins ( 1998 ) , Larsen B ( 2002 ) , Larsen C ( this century ) . Currents undermine the Ross and Ronne ice shelves , enabling ice flows from deep within the West Antarctic Ice Sheet . Arctic permafrost thawed ; glaciers and sea ice retreated . In 30 years the Arctic ice area shrank by 10 % , its thickness by 42 % , opening shorter maritime routes when Arctic sea ice disappears in future summers . Siberian lakes disappeared . Indigenous cultures and glacier tourism suffered . Bird migrations shifted . Northern Hemisphere weather will worsen . In Antarctica and the Artic , ice melts are causing complex questions about the impact of global warming . In Antarctica huge glaciers are thinning and ice shelves are either disintegrating or retreating . These findings are possible indications of global warming . Information gathered about Antarctica coincides with a recent report on accelerating climate changes in Arctic . A Chinese scientist predicted that the Artic icecap would melt by 2080 . the indigenous Artic population are fighting global warming because global warming will be a threat to the indigenous Artic population societies , economies and culture . The thinning of glaciers and ice shelves , as well as the softening of the permafrost , has accelerated greatly in recent years . While it is not certain that the man - made greenhouse effect is entirely to blame , it is clear that man must take steps now to address the problem . Global warming affects everything : oil - platforms , the society of peoples who are indiginous to the polar regions , polar animals , migratory birds , lakes ( which are drying up as the permafrost melts ) , and even tourism . As melting cold fresh water enters the salty sea , melting cold fresh water will affect ocean currents and therefore world climate .

summary: 23 countries recently met in Greenland to encourage governments to act on global warming instead of arguing . Worldwide , countries are agreeing that the U.N. Kyoto Protocol , which commits 39 nations to reduce greenhouse gases , is not enough . Infrastructure in Russia is being damaged due to the melting permafrost including airports , gas pipelines and railways . Wildlife including polar bears , reindeer , seals , and fish are threatened as well as many plant species . Fishing zones are disappearing . Shipping lanes are at risk . The Arctic and Antarctic of today will be radically changed within the next century if action is not taken worldwide . Arctic sea ice is melting faster . Arctic sea ice area is down 20 % and Arctic sea ice could disappear this century . Thinning sea ice threatens extinction of polar bears . Less ice reflects less sunlight , warming the planet , leading to more ice melt and sea - level rise . Greenland and Antarctic ice shelf melting will double the estimated global sea level rise to 1 meter . Arctic permafrost thaw releases warming greenhouse gases , which will increase permafrost melting up to 11 feet deep by 2100 . Greenland ice fishing season has shortened . Lake areas doubled . Glaciers Sermeg , Sermilik , and Kangerdlugssuag melted faster . Alaska 's Columbia glacier also melted faster . Climate change could thaw the top 11 feet of permafrost in most areas of the Northern Hemisphere by 2100 altering ecosystems across Alaska 's , Canada and Russia according to a US study . If thaw occurs , considerable amounts of greenhouse gases could be released into the atmosphere , which could amplify global warming . However , another researcher disagrees that thaw would be so large . another researcher states that Alaska 's permafrost wo n't melt that fast or deep . A group of countries , which fringe the Artic waters , met to discuss measures to reduce greenhouse emissions . Several international meetings have been held to address the issues of global warming and climate change . There continues to be disagreement on whether or not this is the effect of human activity , although scientists agree that something has changed radically and that there are few other explanations . New satellite photos show that Arctic ice is melting faster than before and that air temperatures are rising sharply . And two explorers working with Greenpeace could not complete a trip from Siberia to the North Pole because of the effects of rising temperatures , including broken ice , strong currents , and heavy rainfall .

summary: China sacrificed coal mine safety in China massive demand for energy . Gas explosions , flooding , fires , and cave - ins cause most accidents . The mining industry is riddled with corruption from mining officials to owners . Officials are often illegally invested in mines and ignore safety procedures for production . South Africa recently provided China with information on mining safety and technology during a conference . China is beginning enforcement of safety regulations . Over 12,000 mines have been ordered to suspend operations and 4,000 others ordered closed . This year 4,228 miners were killed in 2,337 coal mine accidents . China mines are the most dangerous worldwide . Chinese coalmines are said to be the most dangerous in the world . January - September 2005 there were 2337 coal - mine accidents killing 4228 people , up 8.5 percent from the rate in 2004 . Accidents included explosions , floods and cave - ins . China has issued mine - safety regulations , but enforcement is ineffective . Mines are shut down for violation of regulations , but the demand for coal is great and many mines owned by local officials quickly reopen without sanction . In August 2005 China ordered all officials with coalmine investments to withdraw all officials with coalmine investments stakes . China 's mines cause thousands of deaths and injuries annually . 2004 saw over 6,000 mine deaths . January through August 2005 2005 , deaths rose 8.5 % over the same period in 2004 . Most accidents are gas explosions , but fires , floods , and cave - ins also occur . Ignored safety procedures , outdated equipment , and corrupted officials exacerbate the problem . Official responses include shutting down thousands of ill - managed and illegally - run mines , punishing errant owners , issuing new safety regulations and measures , and outlawing local officials from investing in mines . China also sought solutions at the Conference on South African Coal Mining Safety Technology and Equipment held in Beijing . China will close 8,648 coal mines during October 2005 , for renewal of safety certificates in view of the large number of mine accidents causing loss of life . During the first nine months of This year , there were 2337 accidents killing 4228 people . Mine safety procedures have been ignored in the quest for profits , especially by those mines owned or partly - owned by local officials . A total of 4,578 officials admitted to having stakes in coal mines . China is seeking solutions from the world , especially South Africa , to improve mining safety . By November , 12,148 mines were ordered shut down for recertification .

summary: The National Bureau of Production Safety Supervision and Administration aims to resolve all small coal mine problems within three years . Meanwhile accidents continue . Measures to improve safety include shorter working hours , fire control and ventilation equipment , and a national network of safety inspectors . Automatic gas monitors were installed in 22 gas - rich coal mines . China fired two provincial deputy governors , prosecuted 96 officials and fired or demoted 126 more after accident investigations . China has created a whistleblowers fund to reward citizens reporting negligence and illegal mine investors . Mine safety remains a major challenge as coal represents 67 % of China energy resource . Government officials have announced that 4,000 small coalmines will be closed by the end of 2005 . One city in north China has imposed huge fines on coalmines for each death in accidents . In Hunan Province cash awards are offered to those who report officials who illegally own shares in mines . In December 2005 China announced that China had dismissed two provincial deputy governors , prosecuted 96 officials and demoted or dismissed 126 other officials blamed for accidents killing 528 people . Despite such measures the rate of large - scale accidents increases with accidents reported on a near - daily basis . Accident and death rates continue to increase at China provincial coal mines , while rates decrease at state - owned facilities . In response , officials will close 4,000 small coal mines annually for three years and further reduce 4,000 small coal mines through regrouping and mergers . Already , 2,411 mines were closed this year and 12,900 were ordered to suspend production for safety problems . Fines have been established for wrongful deaths , and rewards offered to whistleblowers . Advanced gas monitors were installed in 20 - some gas - rich coal mines . two provincial deputy governors were dismissed , 96 officials were prosecuted , and another 126 officials were demoted or fired for safety violations . China has set a timetable for solving the problems associated with 4,000 small coalmines . Many of 4,000 small coalmines will be closed , an action that wo n't affect China demand for coal . Thirteen large coal production bases each capable of turning out 100 M tons annually have been approved . In one region , gas monitors have been installed as a safety measure in gas - rich coalmines . Hunan Province is offering cash rewards to people who report on officials who illegally own shares in coalmines . Some officials have been dismissed . By December 2005 , 12,990 mines were ordered to stop production due to safety problems .

summary: The distress of Hurricane Katrina evacuees forced to choose between rescue and pets has prompted a review of disaster preparedness . Evacuees expected to return within days to rescue Evacuees pets instead of the weeks that have passed . Humane and animal welfare organizations are mounting search and rescue efforts and providing shelter and medical treatment . Humane and animal welfare organizations have requested federal , state and local assistance . Soldiers are being re - deployed for animal rescue . More than 4,000 animals have been rescued with some being sheltered in other states . Animals are micro - chipped and photographed to assist in reunification . Monetary and animal supplies donations are continuing . Hundreds of animal welfare workers and volunteers from the gulf coast and across the nation are working to rescue pets stranded by Hurricane Katrina . The Humane Society , SPCA and other organizations have joined working . SPCA has received donations of over $ 5.25 million , and shipments of food and supplies . Nearly 4,000 animals have been rescued , and 300 - 400 have been reunited with 300 - 400 owners . Hundreds of animals arrive daily at the Lamar - Dixon Center in Gonzales , LA where about 2,000 are housed . Hundreds of animals are photographed , micro chipped and documented before being shipped to other shelters . Pictures are posted on Petfinder.com . Hurricane Katrina evacuees were forced to abandon possibly 50,000 dogs , cats , birds and other pets . Volunteers with The Humane Society , SPCA , other groups , and soldiers searched for pets trapped in houses and left food for animals roaming streets . Rescued pets were taken to Gonzales , LA and Hattiesburg , MS . 4,000 pets had been rescued by 9/13/05 and a small fraction reunited with owners . To ease overcrowding some dogs were relocated to other states after being photographed , microchipped and documented . Pet photographs were posted on the website petfinder.com . Federal , state and local assistance was requested . SPCA received over $ 5.25 million . Hurricane Katrina has left thousands of animals stranded in New Orleans . Many pet owners were forced to abandon Many pet owners animals in the evacuation of New Orleans , although some owners stayed , refusing to leave without some owners pets . The Humane Society and SPCA are doing The Humane Scociety and the SPCA best to rescue thousands of animals . Web sites are being used to try to reunite pets and pets owners . And many animals are being photographed , microchipped , and documented and then shipped to shelters and foster homes in other states .

summary: Three weeks after Katrina pets are still being rescued . 5,000 plus have been rescued but thousands have perished . Emergency responders are voluntarily assisting but humane societies are requesting a policy that local , state and federal responders will diligently assist with pet rescues . Representatives Lantos and Oberstar are co - sponsoring a policy that local , state and federal responders will diligently assist with pet rescues to force local and state governments to create emergency evacuation plans for pets or forfeit FEMA disaster grant eligibility . Rescued animals are being fostered in prisons and other states as local shelters are overwhelmed . Unprecedented millions of dollars are being donated for pet rescue effort . Rescue efforts continue for pets abandoned in the wake of Katrina . Some are still found alive , but estimated tens of thousands have already died . By 10 October , some 8,000 animals have been rescued . At least 600 have been reunited with At least 600 owners . Tens of millions of dollars have been donated for Katrina animal rescue . Animals have been sent from the Lamar - Dixon shelter and another at Louisiana State University to smaller shelters , foster homes and even prisons across the country to await reunions or adoption . the Lamar - Dixon shelter will be shut down on 15 October . Petfinder.com will list pets through 15 December . Five thousand pets have been rescued but time is running out for the rest . Many animals are sick from consuming contaminated water , garbage and carrion . LSU 's Parker Coliseum ( Baton Rouge ) houses over a thousand rescued pets and the Lamar - Dixon shelter holds up to 2,000 , including larger and sicker animals . Staff are from the Humane Society , US Public Health Service , FEMA , and volunteers . Pets are sent to smaller shelters , foster homes , and prisons for longer - term care . Over 600 have been reunited with owners . Rescuing people takes priority but the Humane Society and a bill in Congress urge pet evacuation also . Tens of millions of dollars have been donated to pet charities because of Katrina , but weeks after Katrina , abandoned animals are still a major concern . It is estimated that more than 50,000 pets were left behind . Hundreds arrive at shelters every day , most suffering from at least one ailment , such as dysentery , infection , malnutrition , dehydration . Many died before Many could be rescued . Local shelters are overwhelmed , so some animals are being sent to shelters and foster homes in other states . Two prisons have taken in animals , which the inmates will care for until permanent homes can be found .

summary: Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D has been launched with a bombardment of information to seniors . The enrollment period is from November 15 to May 15 with coverage beginning January 1 . There may be costly penalties for those that do not sign up by the deadline . The majority of seniors are confused and overwhelmed by all the plan choices . Making the wrong choice has the potential to cost more than The majority of seniors are currently paying . Seniors not computer literate must rely on phone representatives newly trained in the plan details . Many seniors are giving up in frustration and not enrolling . Benefits from Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D will not begin until January 1 , 2006 , but Medicare beneficiaries may sign up beginning November 15 . The choice is difficult - not just whether to join , but which of a multitude of plans is best for an individual . Choice of the wrong option can endanger benefits already provided by Medicare or other programs . The problem is so baffling that Medicare has established a hotline and a website to help applicants , but users complain that a website is ponderous and the representatives on a hotline are often misinformed . Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D enrollment for Medicare beneficiaries began November 15 though May 15 for coverage starting January 1 , 2006 , with a 1 % penalty per month for late enrollment . The Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D Drug Discount Card expired May 15 . After a $ 100 - million information campaign , 33 % of seniors felt informed ; 37 % thought 37 % would benefit . Seniors choosing a Medicare Part D - approved private drug insurance plan risk loosing Seniors choosing a Medicare Part D - approved private drug insurance plan other medical insurance . Employers used Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D federal subsidies to reduce retirees ' overall health premiums ; others dropped retiree health plans entirely . Of 40 million elderly Medicare beneficiaries , 28 million will enter Part D. Medicare beneficiaries are eligible for Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D prescription drug coverage . Medicare patients can obtain the drug benefit , which becomes effective January 1 , 2006 , through two types of private plans : a prescription drug plan ( PDP ) or a Medicare Advantage plan ( MA ) . If a senior purchases a Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D plan , any prior drug benefit will be voided . The government will not negotiate prices or discounts under a Part D plan . Employers who offer drug coverage to those over 65 are required to provide comparisons of Employers who offer drug coverage to those over 65 plan and Part D. Medicare has a hotline and Web site to help people confused by Part D.

summary: Open season for Medicare Part D has begun . States and local communities are offering resources in addition to the federal ones to assist enrollees due to Medicare Part D complexities . Medicare is staffing phones round the clock everyday . The Medicare website has been so inundated with traffic that The Medicare website is extremely slow or jammed thus adding to the frustration and anger of enrollees seeking information independently . Due to the extensive criticism of Medicare Part D , some lawmakers are seeking a two - year delay in Medicare Part D implementation . Computer savvy children of seniors are just as confused and baffled over plan details as Computer savvy children of seniors parents . Calls for help have increased sharply since enrollment for Medicare Part D opened . Many organizations and volunteers try to supplement the swamped Medicare lines , but Many organizations and volunteers face developing backlogs and problems training personnel . The multiplicity of options , deductibles , premiums and exceptions make comparisons overwhelming if not impossible . Some lawmakers are suggesting a two - year delay in its implementation . One week into open application , The New York Times declared Medicare Part D as an attempt to do something about drug costs for seniors and at the same time protect drug and insurance companies . & quot;It 's a mess . Medicare Part D 's hopelessly confusing.&quot ; Seniors are daunted by comparing Seniors current coverage with Medicare Part D , baffled by hundreds of complex options , and fearful of picking the wrong Medicare Part D plan with wide - ranging premiums and unpredictable coverage changes , potentially costing Seniors several thousands of dollars more annually . Only 6 % of Medicare beneficiaries visited the balky web - based Medicare Part D plan selection tool . Many drug companies will stop offering free or subsidized promotional drugs to needy seniors . Increased competition among Medicare Part D private providers lowered some premiums , but a Senate report showed Medicare Part D drug prices are 3 % higher than CostCo and Drugstore.com ; 60 % higher than Canada . Medicare Part D intricacies and implementation have been so criticized that some lawmakers a pushing for a two - year delay . Various consumer advocacy groups will assist Medicare enrollees in understanding Plan D. A Medicare spokesman said that Medicare updated the plans and prices every Monday and that an enrollee could change plans every day until the end of 2005 . When Medicare Part D starts on January 1st , an enrollee will be paying the rate quoted at enrollment time . Plan D got off to a rocky start with the beginning of enrollment on November 15 , because of the complexity of the system .

summary: The 7 year legal battles between the husband and parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo over whether to extend Florida resident Terri Schiavo life artificially continue with day to day countermanding legal rulings including Florida Supreme Court . Florida Governor , Jeb Bush , intervened for parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo . The U.S. Supreme Court has refused involvement . State rulings for the husband ordered the immediate removal of Florida resident Terri Schiavo feeding tube . The U.S. Congress met in emergency sessions on behalf of parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo to write legislation allowing a federal court to hear the case . the husband is involved in a seven - year court battle with parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo . the husband has fought for legal permission to remove Shiavo 's feeding tube . Some doctors testified that Florida resident Terri Schiavo is in a persistent vegetative state after a sudden heart attack , with no hope for recovery . parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo insist that Florida resident Terri Schiavo be kept alive . Florida resident Terri Schiavo had no living will or written instructions . a seven - year court battle with her parents is complex . A judge instructed that Shiavo 's feeding tube be the immediate removal of Shiavo 's feeding tube on March 18 , 2005 . the husband legal battle to have Shiavo 's feeding tube the immediate removal of Shiavo 's feeding tube against parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo wishes began in 1993 . Courts ordered Shiavo 's feeding tube removed in 2000 and 2003 . Six days after a 2003 removal Shiavo 's feeding tube was reinserted after Florida 's Governor , Jeb Bush , pushed & quot;Terri 's law&quot ; through the Florida Legislature . Florida 's Supreme Court struck reinserted down as unconstitutional . The U.S. Supreme Court declined to get involved . Florida Judge George Greer ordered Shiavo 's feeding tube be disconnected on 3/18/05 , rebuffing US congressional intervention efforts as having no jurisdiction . The U.S. Congress then passed narrow legislation allowing parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo to appeal to federal courts for tube reinsertion . a seven - year court battle with her parents continues over the fate of Florida resident Terri Schiavo . Doctors say that there is no hope of recovery . parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo want to keep Florida resident Terri Schiavo alive ; the husband says that Florida resident Terri Schiavo would not want to be kept alive artificially . a seven - year court battle with her parents is complicated and has involved state courts at several levels , both state and federal legislatures , and Florida 's Governor , Jeb Bush , as well as the U.S. President . As of 19 March Shiavo 's feeding tube had been removed by court order .

summary: Congress passed and President Bush signed emergency legislation allowing federal review of the Schiavo case . Schiavo parents hope to override state rulings and have Schiavo 's parents daughter 's feeding tube reinserted . Federal judges refused to reverse the Florida court 's ruling . Florida lawmakers refused to re - enter the Schiavo case after the Florida court 's ruling . A Florida court will hear new motions per President Bush . However Schiavo 's parents appeals for reinsertion of their daughter 's feeding tube were denied . After prolonged legal debates including unprecedented Congressional intervention and five U.S. Supreme Court appeals , Schiavo died 18 days after their daughter 's feeding tube was removed . Schiavo died 13 days after their daughter 's feeding tube was removed by order of a Florida judge . Schiavo 's parents continued to fight to keep Schiavo 's parents daughter alive . A federal judge refused to order their daughter 's feeding tube reinserted . President Bush signed died . Florida lawmakers refused to intervene in the Schiavo case . An appeals court and US Circuit court also ruled against Schiavo 's parents . U.S. Supreme Court turned aside the Schiavo case . Schiavo won a malpractice suit concerning Schiavo coma in 1993 . Schiavo first petitioned for feeding tube removal in 1998 . After final tube removal in 2005 , US District Court Judge James Whittemore refused to order reinsertion . Schiavo 's parents appealed to a three - judge federal appeals panel but were rebuffed . Judge Greer issued an injunction keeping the DCF and police away from Schiavo . Courts consistently rejected appeals related to abuse allegations or new medical diagnoses , and efforts to block Schiavo cremation . U.S. Supreme Court again declined involvement . A federal appeals court agreed to consider a new hearing but Schiavo died first . Schiavo died on Thursday 31 March , thirteen days after their daughter 's feeding tube was removed by court order . Schiavo husband has requested an autopsy . In the final two weeks of Schiavo life , at least 47 protestors were arrested and there were numerous appeals to have their daughter 's feeding tube reinserted . Efforts even included a congressional bill to shift jurisdiction from state to federal courts and President Bush rush back from Texas to sign a congressional bill to shift jurisdiction from state to federal courts . In Florida President Bush tried to get custody transferred to Florida . And the Schiavo case bounced back and forth in state and federal courts .

summary: Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald is investigating who leaked to the press that Valerie Plame , wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson , was an undercover CIA agent . former Ambassador Joseph Wilson was a critic of the Bush administration . Administration staffers Karl Rove and I. Lewis Libby are the focus of investigating . NY Times correspondent Judith Miller was jailed for 85 days for refusing to testify about I. Lewis Libby . I. Lewis Libby was eventually indicted on five counts : 2 false statements , 1 obstruction of justice , 2 perjury . I. Lewis Libby resigned immediately . I. Lewis Libby faces 30 years in prison and a fine of $ 1.25 million if convicted . I. Lewis Libby pleaded not guilty . On October 28 , 2005 I. Lewis Libby was indicted on five counts : 2 false statements , 1 obstruction of justice , 2 perjury , by Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald investigation into possible intentional , illegal revelation of the identify of Valerie Plame , wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson . I. Lewis Libby testimony was contradicted by several witnesses . No others were indicted as the grand jury was extended and Karl Rove remains under investigation . I. Lewis Libby will fight five counts : 2 false statements , 1 obstruction of justice , 2 perjury . NY Times correspondent Judith Miller had been jailed 85 days before testifying and surrendering notes , after I. Lewis Libby formally rescinded their confidential source agreement . Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald investigation into the naming of Valerie Plame , wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson as an undercover CIA agent has led to a parade of newspersons and White House staffers before the grand jury . Columnist Robert Novak first revealed Valerie Plame , wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson . NY Times reporter Judith Miller was jailed 85 days for refusing to testify about Lewis & quot;Scooter&quot ; I. Lewis Libby . Karl Rove is under investigation . I. Lewis Libby resigned after being indicted on five counts : 2 false statements , 1 obstruction of justice , 2 perjury . I. Lewis Libby has pled not guilty . After a nearly two - year investigation in the CIA leak case , I. Lewis Libby was indicted on felony charges of perjury , making false statements to FBI agents , and obstruction of justice for impeding the grand jury . I. Lewis Libby resigned immediately . If convicted , I. Lewis Libby faces a maximum of 30 years in prison and a 1.25 million dollar fine . I. Lewis Libby said I. Lewis Libby plans to fight five counts : 2 false statements , 1 obstruction of justice , 2 perjury . Karl Rove was not indicted but still faces the possibility of prosecution as investigating continues .

summary: Rove remains under investigation . News organizations are requesting that the court refuse Fitzgerald 's motion to keep pretrial evidence confidential . Plame is leaving the CIA . Senator Charles Schumer requested that President Bush reveal who illegally leaked Plame identity . Libby 's trial has been set to begin in January . Libby 's lawyers seek dismissal of charges against Libby 's saying that Fitzgerald 's did not have the legal authority to indict Libby 's . By court order , edited government documents related to intelligence briefings will be provided to Libby 's for Libby 's defense . Fitzgerald 's opposed seek saying Fitzgerald 's had the legal authority to indict . After Libby 's indictment , reporter Bob Woodward told Fitzgerald 's that about one month before Plame 's identity was exposed , reporter Bob Woodward had learned Plame 's identity from another President Bush administration official ( not Libby 's ) . Rove revealed Plame 's identity to Time magazine reporter Matt Cooper days before Libby 's revealed Plame 's identity to columnist Robert Novak . Portions of the Plame identity leak investigation 's grand jury testimony were unsealed . Libby 's had told the grand jury that Vice President Cheney had authorized Libby 's to leak classified information . Fitzgerald 's disputed Libby 's motion to a federal judge to dismiss Libby 's indictment , claiming Fitzgerald 's was appointed unconstitutionally . reporter Bob Woodward acknowledged that a senior WH official , other than Libby 's , had told reporter Bob Woodward Plame was a the CIA operative before Plame 's identity was reported by columnist Robert Novak . Plame resigned from the CIA since Plame outing diminished Plame career possibilities . Rove remains under investigation ; Rove disclosed that Rove had told a Time magazine reporter of Plame the CIA status . Libby 's lawyers continue to argue for dismissal of the case . It was reported that Libby 's will argue that Vice President Cheney authorized Libby 's to leak classified information to bolster the case for war against Iraq . Libby 's lawyers have asked a federal judge to dismiss Libby 's indictment , claiming that Fitzgerald 's lacked the legal authority to indict Libby 's . Fitzgerald 's disputes claiming . Libby 's trial has been set for January 2007 . Libby 's is expected to testify that Libby 's was too involved with national security issues to recall minor events such as conversations with reporters . A federal judge has ordered the government to provide Libby 's with redacted versions of various documents and other information Libby 's requested . Meanwhile Fitzgerald 's is back at work before another grand jury with Rove still under investigation .

summary: Christians constitute about three percent of Iraq 's population of 25 million . In August 2004 five churches in Baghdad and Mosul were blown up and in the following two months it is estimated that 15,000 Christians left for Syria and Jordan . Many of 15,000 Christians blamed the attacks not on Muslim Iraqis but on foreigners . By January 2005 the Christian minority was organized into political parties in preparation for the January 30th parliamentary elections . On January 15th gunmen kidnapped the Syrian Archbishop of Mosul , kidnapped . Iraqi Christians who are increasingly targeted by insurgents are leaving Baghdad for the Kurdish north , Syria and Jordan . leaving is temporary because Iraqi Christians who are increasingly targeted by insurgents are n't selling Iraqi Christians who are increasingly targeted by insurgents homes and property . About 15,000 of Iraqi nearly 1 million Christians have left Iraq 's since August 2004 . Insurgents abducted the Syrian Archbishop of Mosul apparently to frighten Iraqi Christians in upcoming elections . Former Archbishop of Canterbury launched a campaign to assure the future of Iraqi Christian community . Iraqi Christian community rights should be enshrined in the new Iraqi constitution and financial aid given for return to Iraqi Christian community lands and homes . Assyrian Christians in Iraq 's date to the pre - Islamic first century . Modern day Christians have represented three percent of Iraq 's population . Muslims regularly persecuted Christians , intent on driving Christians out . Iraqi Christians ' future looked brighter after Saddam 's fall but now looks worse , even though freedom of religion was stipulated in the new Iraqi constitution . Since the war began , over 100 Christians have been killed . Militants target Christians and try to shut Christians worldly business and keep Christians from voting . Fifteen thousand Christians have left Iraq 's . Twelve churches were bombed . The Chaldean patriarch 's home was attacked and the Syrian Archbishop of Mosul was kidnapped . Christians make up about three percent of Iraq 's population . Since the war started , armed attacks have led many to leave Iraq 's , mostly for Syria and Jordan . five churches in Baghdad and Mosul have been attacked and more than 100 Christians have been killed , with many more wounded . Those targeted have included people helping the U.S.-led forces , as well as those in occupations seen as breaking Islamic law , such as owners of liquor - stores and beauty parlors . In mid - January , just before the January 30th parliamentary elections , a Catholic archbishop was kidnapped by gunmen in Mosul .

summary: The Jan.30 , 2005 election produced only one seat for Christian Parties in the 275 - seat Iraq National Assembly . Christians protested irregularities which prevented many from voting . Now the main concern was that minority rights be enshrined in the constitution to be written by the 275 - seat Iraq National Assembly . On March 16 , 2005 a Christian general in the Iraqi police force was shot dead by a group affiliated with Al - Qaeda . In November in Baghdad gunmen killed four Christian women . Emigration of Iraqi Christians continues with the number since the American takeover estimated from 20,000 to 200,000 . US members of the Iraqi Christian minority living in the US voiced hope for national unity in Iraq 's first free elections . Hundreds of Iraqi Christians protested voting irregularities outside of Baghdad Green Zone . Many polling places opened late or never opened . Those that opened did n't have ballots or election material . Although not written yet , Iraqi Christians fear that the constitution to be written by the National Assembly will favor Islam over Christianity . More killings of Christian Iraqis occur including a Christian general . Yet , Christian Iraqis celebrate Christmas and some hope to flee Iraq 's . Christians in Mosul protested polls not opening for & quot;security reasons&quot ; , keeping 200,000 from voting . Christians won one National Rafidain List seat in the 275 - seat Iraq National Assembly and five spots on Kurdish and PM Alawi tickets . Christians demand the constitution to be written by the National Assembly not be based solely on the Koran and include religious freedom . A Christian police general was assassinated in Kirkuk and four Christian women were murdered in Baghdad . Catholics celebrated a mass for Pope John Paul II . Christmas celebrations became low - key . The Roman Catholic community in Baghdad fell from 60,000 to 5,000 . A bombed church was rebuilt with a high wall . In January elections , Christians won only six seats in the 275 - seat Iraq National Assembly . Outside Baghdad 's Green Zone Christians protested voting irregularities . The 71 - member committee drafting the constitution to be written by the National Assembly included only one Christian , leading to fears that the constitution to be written by the National Assembly would not recognize minority religious rights . Christians gathered under police protection for a special mass for Pope John Paul II . But violence continued . A Christian police general was killed in Kirkuk . Gunmen killed four Christan women in a Baghdad Christian neighborhood . And some churches were surrounded by tall walls and guarded with rifles . For safety , Christmas midnight mass was held in daylight .

summary: Felt is in poor health and Felt family acknowledged that money was a factor in revealing Felt secret . his family have agreed to the publication of a combination autobiography / biography and have signed a movie deal . L. Patrick Gray III , Acting Director of the FBI during the Watergate crisis expressed anger , shock , and betrayal at revealing . a combination autobiography / biography reports that Felt had inadvertently revealed Felt role to Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger while being questioned during a grand jury hearing in 1976 . Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger told Woodward 's that Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger would not reveal Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger unconfirmed conclusion and Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger did n't thus protecting Woodward 's source . In early June a retired the FBI official claimed that several other bureau officials & quot;all since deceased&quot ; had collaborated with Felt in Felt role as & quot;Deep Throat.&quot ; On June 6 Felt daughter acknowledged that money played a role in his family decision to go public . It was announced on June 15 that his family had chosen a publisher for a book to be released next spring and given movie options for the Felt life story . On July 5 Woodward 's book & quot;The Secret Man&quot ; appeared in stores revealing more details of Felt role as & quot;Deep Throat.&quot ; ----------------- D0809 - B.M.100.B.D ----------------- ----------------- D0809 - B.M.100.B.F -----------------

summary: On Sept. 22 , 2004 the Office of Federal Enterprise Oversight cited numerous accounting irregularities in mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines . It was charged that earnings were doctored to inflate executive compensation . Franklin Raines could possibly face not only loss of Franklin Raines position , but fines and prison for falsifying financial statements . On Dec. 15 the Securities and Exchange Commission concluded that mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines had indeed violated accounting rules . Lawmakers called for return of millions in executive bonuses . Franklin Raines received $ 14 million in salary and $ 25 million in incentive pay 2001 - 2003 . Franklin Raines defended mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines accounting . As late as December 21 , 2004 , Franklin Raines was said to be still under criminal investigation by the Justice Department for alleged financial accounting manipulations at mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines . It is not clear if Franklin Raines was ever under criminal investigation related to criminal charges against Time Warner and AOL , which the two companies together paid over $ 500 million to settle in December 2004 . criminal charges against Time Warner and AOL , which the two companies together paid over $ 500 million to settle in December 2004 stemmed from alleged fraudulent accounting practices dating back to when AOL was a separate company and Franklin Raines was a member of AOL audit committee . Franklin Raines is defending mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines accounting practices and disagrees with allegations that mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines violated rules to maximize executive bonuses . mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines will be investigated by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission and faces litigation by shareholders . Franklin Raines and other executives could not only lose Raines and other executives jobs , but also face fines and prison for knowingly certifying false financial statements . Raines and other executives can be compelled to give back incentive pay and gains from sale of stock . Major concerns have arisen over the leadership and credibility of mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines CEO Franklin Raines . The regulatory agency known as OFHEO conducted the Initial investigations into its accounting practices and found that mortgage giant Fannie Mae ( Fannie ) headed by Franklin Raines had violated accounting rules to present a picture of financial well - being and to maximize executive bonuses . Franklin Raines has had to testify before the House Financial Services Committee . the Justice Department is conducting an investigation . the Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into company accounting practices . The U.S. attorney 's office is pursuing a criminal investigation . And eight lawsuits have been filed on behalf of shareholders .

summary: The directors of Fannie met on Dec. 19 to decide Raines ' fate , but met concluded without any announcement of a decision . On Dec. 21 Raines ' resigned with Raines ' departure structured as an early retirement . The directors of Fannie decision in favor of Raines ' retirement rather than dismissal would reap Raines ' $ 8.7 million in deferred payments and an annual pension of more than $ 1 million . On Jan. 21 , 2005 , however , Fannie announced that Raines ' would be denied the cash bonus that Raines ' would have received for 2004 . By October 12 , 2004 the U.S. Attorney 's Office in Washington was investigating Fannie CEO Franklin Raines , who denied wrongdoing , after a caustic September 22 Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report vetted by the SEC , charged that Fannie violated Financial Accounting Standard 133 and FAS-91 , inflating Fannie reported net earnings by $ 9 billion , so that Raines ' and other top executives received maximum bonuses of $ 27.1 million vice no bonuses , and got higher , allegedly manipulated , prices for Raines and other top executives own sales of Fannie stock . The Justice Department told Fannie to preserve documents related to a caustic September 22 Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report vetted by the SEC , . Raines ' testified to Congress that Raines ' expected to be held accountable if Raines ' interpretation of the accounting rules was not accepted . The chief accountant of the SEC ruled that Fannie violated accounting standards overstating Fannie profits by 38 percent since January 2001 . Raines ' is seeking a vote of confidence from The directors of Fannie as Raines ' struggles to survive criminal investigation . Raines ' retired under pressure from federal regulators . Raines ' will be denied bonuses for 2004 as Fannie eliminated bonuses for top executives . the SEC ruled that Fannie had overstated its profits by 38 per cent in the years 2001 - 2004 . The OFHEO held Raines ' responsible Fannie emphasisis on earnings over accuracy and demanded significant changes in senior management . On 21 December , Raines ' took early retirement with millions of dollars in benefits and stock , plus an annual pension of over one million dollars . Fannie still faced a The Justice Department criminal investigation , an the SEC civil investigation , further Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight examination of Fannie accounting , and several class - action lawsuits . As of 21 January , Fannie was withholding millions in bonuses for top executives .

summary: Debate continues on whether Pluto discovered in 1930 is a planet or a Kuiper Belt Object ( KBO ) . Up to 100,000 bodies may be in the Kuiper Belt . There is no standard definition of planet and no limit to potential new planets . Pluto discovered in 1930 small size , odd orbit and orbital plane is closer to a KBO than a planet . The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto discovered in 1930 is larger and similar in composition . The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto is very bright with a skewed orbit and a moon . The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto mass will be determined from a moon . The International Astronomical Union will decide if The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto is a planet . Astronomers have questioned whether Pluto discovered in 1930 is a planet or a Kuiper Belt Object ( KBO ) , one of a belt of comets , asteroids and other objects at the edge of the solar system . Then on July 29 , 2005 Caltech astronomer Michael A. Brown announced discovery of The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto . The question : is The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto the tenth planet or should The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto and Pluto discovered in 1930 both be considered KBOs ? On Sept. 10 , Caltech astronomer Michael A. Brown announced that The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto , has a moon . The discovery of The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto in the Kuiper Belt , will likely rekindle he debate over the definition of & quot;planet.&quot ; Until recently , Pluto discovered in 1930 has been accepted for generations as the ninth planet of the solar system despite Pluto discovered in 1930 small size and long elliptical orbit angled to the orbital plane of the eight & quot;inner&quot ; planets . Like the eight & quot;inner&quot ; planets , Pluto discovered in 1930 is spherical , has an atmosphere and seasons and a moon . If Pluto discovered in 1930 is considered a planet then The recently discovered 2003 UB313 beyond Pluto is also a planet . Other Kuiper Belt Objects might also merit consideration . Pluto discovered in 1930 was named the ninth planet because , though small , Pluto discovered in 1930 is round like other planets , and has an atmosphere , seasons , and moon . Astronomers now debate downgrading Pluto discovered in 1930 to Kuiper Belt Object ( KBO ) because of Pluto discovered in 1930 similarity to other icy bodies orbiting beyond Neptune . KBOs are being accurately studied by the orbiting Spitzer Space Telescope . A possible new planet in 2005 is 2003 UB313 ( 2003 EL61 ) , nicknamed Xena . Spanish astronomers also allege discovery of a new body designated 2003 UB313 which is larger than Pluto with a surface very similar to Pluto . & quot;Planet&quot ; has no official definition . 2003 UB313 ( 2003 EL61 ) , nicknamed Xena is similar to Pluto discovered in 1930 , has a moon , also orbits at an angle , and is twice Pluto discovered in 1930 size .

summary: After 18 months the International Astronomical Union has still not determined the criteria for planethood . Pluto 's eventual status will also define new space objects . However the data from the Pluto space probe in 2015 will come too late to settle this argument . Recent discovery of two additional moons around Pluto 's complicate the issue . The diameter of Pluto 's and UB313 is about 1,380 and 1,800 miles respectively and Pluto and UB313 have methane ice on Pluto and UB313 surfaces . Proposed definitions based on size or gravitational pull either include or exclude Pluto and UB313 . The scientific deadlock at the International Astronomical Union will not be resolved quickly . A committee of the International Astronomical Union ( IAU ) is considering the question of planethood of Pluto and UB313 . Pluto and UB313 might be called & quot;minor planets&quot ; or could be considered KBOs . NASA 's Hubble Space telescope strengthened Pluto 's claim to planethood by finding two additional moons around Pluto . On Jan 20 , 2006 NASA 's launched NASA 's New Horizon spacecraft to explore Pluto 's and the Kuiper Belt which its New Horizon spacecraft is scheduled to reach in July 2015 . Meanwhile German astronomers determined that the diameter of UB313 is 1800 miles compared to Pluto 's 1380 . A committee of the International Astronomical Union ( IAU ) continues to deliberate . Debate continues over what constitutes a planet . Some astronomers say a planet should have a diameter greater than 2,000 kilometers ( Pluto and UB313 do ) . Another suggestion is roundness : Another suggestion would include Pluto and UB313 and likely several others yet unknown . Another possible definition is that a planet must gravitationally dominate a planet surroundings , which would exclude Pluto and UB313 . Pluto 's became more interesting when NASA 's Hubble Space telescope discoverd that Pluto 's had not just one but three moons . Scientific interest in Pluto 's and Kuiper Belt objects led to the New Horizons spacecraft mission : a nine year trip to Pluto 's and beyond . Scientists debate redefining & quot;planet&quot ; or retiring & quot;planet&quot . KBO 2003 UB313 , discovered by Michael E. Brown , was confirmed by surface heat emanations to be 30 percent larger than Pluto 's . Both have surface methane ice . If Pluto 's is a planet , UB313 should be too . NASA 's Hubble Space telescope showed two more small moons orbiting Pluto 's , 30 - 100 miles in diameter . Pluto and UB313 , may be a binary planet system orbiting a center mass between Pluto and UB313 . At least four KBOs have known moons . Pluto 's would be the first KBO to have multiple satellites .

summary: After Mikhail Saakashvili replaced Eduard Shevardnadze as the Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili vowed to reunite the separatist pro - Russian regions of Georgia and fight against corruption . Adzharia was reunited but not Abkhazia and South Ossetia . Conflicts in the separatist pro - Russian regions of Georgia include officials screening ship passengers , the threatening of boats in Georgian waters , and the suppression of press critical of Mikhail Saakashvili . Mikhail Saakashvili has the support of the United States in efforts to bring democracy to Georgia without war . Meetings are being held with region leaders mediated by the Russian Foreign Ministry . Mikhail Saakashvili seeks an agreement between Georgia and Russia to be signed by Putin . Mikhail Saakashvili won the Georgian President in Jan. 2004 vowing to regain the separatist pro - Russian regions of Georgia . Mikhail Saakashvili was successful in restoring Adzharia but has made little headway in the other two . In May Mikhail Saakashvili sent troops into South Ossetia culminating in an indecisive temporary cease - fire agreement in August . August Mikhail Saakashvili threatened ships bound for Abkhazian ports . Mikhail Saakashvili offered & quot;the wildest possible autonomy,&quot ; but Mikhail Saakashvili bid to open talks was rejected by the Abkhazians . By Jan. 2005 Mikhail Saakashvili was promising official proposals to Abkhazia and South Ossetia by the end of the month . In January 2004 , Mikhail Saakashvili regained control of Adzharia . Georgia searched ships arriving in Abkhazia . Mikhail Saakashvili offered & quot;widest possible autonomy&quot ; to Abkhazia and South Ossetia . Georgian troops entered South Ossetia despite threats of Russian intervention . Georgian coast guards fired on a Turkish ship near Abkhazia . Georgia threatened withdrawal from the Commonwealth of Independent States . Georgia and Russia agreed to mutual withdrawal of troops . Georgia said Georgia would not start a war and denied stationing 700 troops on the Abkhazia border . Mikhail Saakashvili was to make official proposals to Abkhazia and South Ossetia and finalize a framework agreement on relations with Russia . Mikhail Saakashvili priority is to reunite the separatist pro - Russian regions of Georgia with Georgia . Mikhail Saakashvili succeeded in Adzharia , but not in Abkhazia and South Ossetia . Mikhail Saakashvili has sent troops to Abkhazia and South Ossetia during times of heightened tensions and engaged in on - again off - again negotiations with Abkhazia and South Ossetia . Mikhail Saakashvili ordered Georgian authorities to screen ships arriving in Abkhazia , threatened to sink Russian tour boats , and had coast guards fire on a Turkish ship . Mikhail Saakashvili closed down South Ossetia trade in smuggled Russian goods . Mikhail Saakashvili is seeking better relations with Moscow to improve relations with Abkhazia and South Ossetia , and will soon present official proposals to Moscow .

summary: Conflicts continue between the separatist regions and Georgia . Peace processes are being disrupted by kidnappings and the suspicious accidental death of Prime Minister Zhvania as Prime Minister Zhvania was seeking a negotiated settlement . Saakashvili met with President Bush to discuss Georgian plans to resolve the separatist conflicts . Saakashvili and Moldovan President Voronin criticized the separatists in ex - Soviet republics . Saakashvili and Moldovan President Voronin are joining forces to seek solutions . Saakashvili calls for a new Yalta conference to consolidate democracy in Georgia and other countries . Georgian and Abkhazia separatist officials continue to negotiate peace overseen by United Nations monitors . the separatist regions still firmly maintain the separatist regions independence . On Jan. 19 , 2005 South Ossetians abducted two Georgian police officers in an attempt to disrupt any peace talks . In Abkhazia the new elected president pledged to fight on for international recognition of Abkhazia de facto independence . On Jan. 26 Saakashvili offer of autonomy was immediately rejected by South Ossetia . Saakashvili then turned to the international scene presenting Georgia as a force for liberty and freedom as opposed to the separatist regions which & quot;are the last razor - sharp splinters of the Soviet Empire.&quot ; As of May 2005 Abkhazia and South Ossetia were still independent from Georgia . Georgia refused to exchange Ossetian prisoners for Georgians captured by South Ossetia . Saakashvili asked Russia to help reunite Abkhazia and South Ossetia with Georgia . Saakashvili told the Council of Europe that autonomy for Abkhazia and South Ossetia would comprise & quot;a local government elected freely and directly , that would include an executive branch and a parliament&quot ; . Georgia and Moldovia issued a joint declaration against separatist movements . Saakashvili called for a & quot;new Yalta conference&quot ; , to extend & quot;liberty&quot ; throughout the Black Sea region . Georgia and Abkhazia met with a United Nations envoy to form a joint group to manage mine removal and ceasefire violations . Saakashvili told European parliamentarians Saakashvili would give more independence to separatist regions , as long as Georgia remains whole . South Ossetia immediately rejected Saakashvili 's offer of autonomy . Peace talks broke down when two Georgian police officers were abducted and 12 Ossetians were abducted in response . Georgian and Abkhazian officials met with a United Nations envoy to discuss security issues and agreed to meet again in mid - June . Saakashvili discussed the issue with President Bush . Saakashvili called for a new Yalta conference to extend the rule of liberty throughout the Black Sea region . Saakashvili and Moldovan President Voronin issued a joint declaration against separatism .

summary: In the Nov. 2 , 2004 election for Governor of Washington , the first vote count showed Republican Rossi leading by 800 votes . The following day Democrat Gregoire led by 1400 ; the next day Democrat Gregoire by 21,234 ; and by Nov. 16 Republican Rossi by 19 . By Nov 18 all votes were counted and Republican Rossi led by 261 . A machine recount gave Republican Rossi a 42 - vote edge but a manual recount gave Democrat Gregoire a lead of 261 . On Dec. 30 Democrat Gregoire was declared Governor - elect . On Jan. 7 , 2005 , with inauguration scheduled for Jan. 12 , Republican Rossi filed a lawsuit seeking a new election . Democrat Christine Grigoire was declared winner in the Nov. 2 , 2004 election for Governor of Washington two months after election day , winning by 129 votes out of 2.9 million cast . Republican Rossi filed a lawsuit seeking the extraordinary remedy of a new election . the first vote count had Republican Rossi ahead by 261 votes . A machine recount reduced Republican Rossi lead to 42 votes . a manual recount put Democrat Christine Grigoire ahead . An estimated 60 % of Washingtonians vote by mail and absentee ballots can be postmarked as late as election day so counting in close races can drag on for weeks . Until the last days of the campaign , Democrat Gregoire was favored to win Washington 2004 governor 's race over Republican Rossi . Absentee ballots postmarked by election day trickled in . Republican Rossi led by 261 votes , triggering a recount required by law if the margin is less than 2000 . Following A machine recount , Republican Rossi led by 42 votes . A third count , by hand , took place after Democrats raised sufficient money . Election officials discovered over 700 erroneously rejected or misplaced absentee ballots . Seven weeks after election day , Democrat Gregoire led by 130 votes , reversing election results . Washington 's 2004 governor 's race was extremely close . the first vote count showed Republican Rossi ahead by 261 votes out of 2.9 million . A machine recount showed Republican Rossi ahead by only 42 votes . a manual recount gave Democrat Gregoire a 120 - vote lead and Democrat Gregoire was declared the winner on 30 December , fifty eight days after the Nov. 2 , 2004 election for Governor of Washington . Republican Rossi has filed a lawsuit , alleging that dead people , felons , and other ineligible voters cast ballots and demanding an unprecedented statewide re - vote . inauguration may be postponed .

summary: Christine A. Gregoire was sworn in as the new governor on Jan. 12 , 2005 . In the first action on Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Christine A. Gregoire the Judge declared that the Judge courtroom and not the Democratic - controlled legislature was the proper forum to investigate the election . The case was scheduled to go to trial May 23 . Although Democrats acknowledged human errors in vote counting , Democrats vigorously denied Republican charges of fraud . Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Gregoire was dismissed on June 6 for lack of evidence and Dino Rossi 's did not appeal to the Supreme Court . sworn occurred amid a legal challenge by Dino Rossi 's . the Judge ruled that the Judge court rather than the Democratic - controlled legislature would investigate the election . the Judge ruled that before ordering a new election or declaring Dino Rossi 's the winner , Republicans would need to prove Dino Rossi 's received more votes than Christine A. Gregoire after supposed illegal votes were deducted . the Judge noted that the only proven illegal votes had been for Dino Rossi 's . Five months after sworn , the Judge dismissed Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Gregoire . After dismissed , Dino Rossi 's ended Dino Rossi 's legal effort to remove Christine A. Gregoire . Christine A. Gregoire was sworn in as governor and proceeded to govern as if elected by landslide , imposing taxes and improving roads . Dino Rossi 's sued for a revote in Republican - leaning , rural Chelan County , claiming illegal votes by felons and ballot - box stuffing . Most Washingtonians opposed a revote . Constitutional language on contested races was ambiguous . the Judge heard The case without a jury . the Judge dismissed Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Gregoire because Dino Rossi 's lawyers failed to meet Rossi 's lawyers burden of proof . Most of illegal votes by felons were for Dino Rossi 's . Dino Rossi 's ended Dino Rossi 's efforts to remove Christine A. Gregoire . Christine A. Gregoire was sworn in as governor of Washington 's on 12 January after the election . The Republicans Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Gregoire to overturn the election , charging election fraud . A judge dismissed Dino Rossi 's lawsuit to oust Gregoire on June 6 , asserting that there were human errors but no fraud , and Dino Rossi 's decided to end Dino Rossi 's 5 - month legal fight . Christine A. Gregoire was declared the winner in late June by the Washington 's Secretary of State . Meanwhile , by the end of the month Dino Rossi 's vowed to continue Dino Rossi 's fight and called for a new vote .

summary: Sudan and Darfur 's two main rebel groups , the Sudan Liberation Army and the Justice and Equality Movement , signed a ceasefire in Ndjamena in April , 2004 . On October 6 , the UK prime minister visited Sudan to discuss Darfur 's . AU - lead peace talks in Abuja between Darfur 's two main rebel groups , the Sudan Liberation Army and the Justice and Equality Movement and Sudan ran August 23 through September 17 , reconvened October 21 , but were suspended by the AU on October 27 . Libya hosted a & quot;mini - summit&quot ; with leaders of Sudan , Egypt , Nigeria , Chad and the JEM in Tripoli on October 17 - 21 ; SLA declined . EU and the AU officials met October 23 - 24 in Khartoum with the Sudan President . Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi , called for a Darfur 's mini - summit to be held on October 21 , 2004 in Sirte , Libya . Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi invited the presidents of Sudan , Egypt , Chad , Nigeria and the leaders of Darfur 's two main rebel groups , the Sudan Liberation Army and the Justice and Equality Movement . Talks between Darfur 's rebels and Sudan were held in Abuja in August and September 2004 . The next round of talks will be held as part of a Darfur mini - summit . This was done to obtain cooperation from neighboring countries , which is crucial to lasting peace . Libya and the African Union have invited Sudanese President Omar al - Beshir to attend a mini - summit in Libya on October 21st with Sudan , Egypt , Chad , Nigeria . Originally set for Sirte , Libyan , a mini - summit in Libya on October 21st with Chad , Egypt and Nigeria was later shifted to Tripoli . Earlier talks had been held in Abuja in August and September . the Sudan Liberation Army would not attend a mini - summit in Libya on October 21st with Chad , Egypt and Nigeria . British PM Tony Blair planned to meet in Addis Abbaba , Ethiopia with Nigerian President and current the AU chairman Olusegun Obasanjo . Peace talks between Sudan and rebel groups in Abuja , adjourned but would resume after Ramadan . The latest Darfur 's peace talks opened on 24 October in Abuja . Sponsored by the African Union , The latest Darfur peace talks were expected to last at least three weeks . The latest Darfur peace talks were adjourned on Wednesday morning so that the AU mediators could prepare a document for discussion that same afternoon . An earlier the AU summit in Abuja concerning the Darfur 's crisis collapsed on 18 September when the two sides disagreed on security issues . Foreign ministers from Libya , Sudan , Egypt , Nigeria , and Chad had met in Libya on 16 October to prepare for An earlier AU summit in Abuja concerning the Darfur crisis .

summary: The second round of AU - lead peace talks in Abuja that was temporarily suspended on October 27 , 2004 , ended November 10 with Sudan , SLA , and JEM signing security and humanitarian protocols . A third , hopeful round of AU - lead peace talks began in Abuja on December 11 , 2004 , seeking a political settlement . SLA and JEM pulled out of the peace talks on December 13 , which were suspended until January , even as rebels vowed never to return until Sudan stopped attacking . December 14 - 17 in Ndjamena , Darfur 's National Movement for Reconstruction and Development signed a separate AU - lead peace pact with Sudan . Peace talks on the crisis in Sudan Darfur region restart . But rebel leaders pulled out of Peace talks on the crisis in Sudan 's Darfur region accusing Sudan of repeatedly breaching a ceasefire agreement . The African Union is trying to put peace negotiations back on track . rebel leaders vowed never to resume the negotiation process unless Sudan ends Sudan attacks and withdraws from Sudan 's Darfur region . Peace talks between Sudan and rebel leaders have been suspended until January 2005 . the Sudanese government and the rebel groups promised to conclude two years of talks , now in Naivasha , with a peace accord . Separate talks with two Darfur 's rebel groups which stopped on November 24 , are to resume on December 10 . A third , hopeful round of AU - lead peace talks were halted when rebel leaders pulled out . The African Union announced that A third , hopeful round of AU - lead peace talks have been suspended until January 2005 . A third rebel group signed a peace pact with the Khartoum government at talks in Chad . The third round of AU - lead talks , which started in Abuja on 10 December after a one - day delay for logistical problems , were suspended on 12 December when the rebels walked out . The two sides traded accusations of ceasefire violations . The third round of AU - sponsored talks , which started in Abuja on 10 December after a one - day delay for logistical problems are expected to resume in January despite statements by the AU - lead mediator that The third round of AU - sponsored talks , which started in Abuja on 10 December after a one - day delay for logistical problems had not been suspended but would resume the following day . A third rebel group signed a peace pact with the Khartoum governmenton 17 December at talks in Chad .

summary: The U.S. Senate remains deadlocked in confirmation proceedings for Justice Janice Rogers Brown for the U.S. Appeals Court in the District of Columbia . Democrats are threatening filibusters to block Justice Janice Rogers Brown confirmation because Justice Janice Rogers Brown judicial views are considered extreme . The The U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee engaged in angry debates . Republicans are threatening the ' nuclear option ' as a means to end any filibusters . Republicans dismissed a Democratic proposal because a Democratic proposal did not include the removal of filibusters . Additional compromise talks ended unsuccessfully . A new proposed agreement would allow Democrats to filibuster only in extreme circumstances . A new confirmation vote date has not been determined . On April 21 , 2005 The Senate Judiciary Committee voted to revive the long dormant nomination of Justice Janice Rogers Brown to the U.S. Appeals Court in the District of Columbia . the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia had been blocked by Democratic filibuster during President Bush 's first term . The U.S. Senate leaders began negotiations over various compromise proposals on handling judicial nominations with Senate leaders threatening to rule out the filibuster . By May 17 it appeared that the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia would not reach the The U.S. Senate floor for another week or perhaps not until after Memorial Day . In April 2005 , The Senate Judiciary Committee approved and sent for The U.S. Senate confirmation , the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia . Democratic The U.S. Senate Minority Leader Reid promised to filibuster against Justice Janice Rogers Brown . Republican The U.S. Senate Majority leader Frist threatened a parliamentary maneuver to change The U.S. Senate rules to permanently eliminate filibusters in judicial confirmations , including Supreme Court nominees . Six Republican Senators and six Democratic Senators considered a pact to vote to prevent judicial filibusters , except in & quot;extreme circumstances&quot ; , and defeat filibuster rule changes . The vote on her confirmation was expected in late May. the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia will soon go before The U.S. Senate . Republicans plan to use the ' nuclear option ' . Moderate Democratic and Republican senators have been trying to work out a compromise that would enable confirmation votes to move forward without such a rule change , so far unsuccessfully . Democrats oppose the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia , claiming Justice Janice Rogers Brown would advance her judicial views , particularly on issues regarding parental notification of abortions for minors . Republicans claim Justice Janice Rogers Brown is independent and hard - working , with an open mind and a lot of common sense .

summary: Debates continue in an effort to reach a compromise on Senate procedures for judicial nominees . Democrats feel the re - nomination of judges found unacceptable to Democrats unprecedented . Both parties are using Brown 's race , African American , in support of Both parties opposite positions on Brown 's . Black members of Congress oppose Brown 's confirmation . A compromise agreement was reached . Democrats will oppose any filibuster attempts regarding Brown 's confirmation but the filibuster rules will remain unchanged . The successful cloture vote to end debate on Brown 's will now permit an up - or - down confirmation vote . After a 2 year delay Brown 's was confirmed by a 56 - 43 vote . As Senate debated the issue of filibustering judicial nominations , a bipartisan group of centrist senators kept working on possible compromise solutions . On May 23 , 14 moderate senators announced an agreement under which Democrats would vote to end debate on three nominations including Brown 's , while Republicans agreed to oppose any attempt to change filibuster rules . On June 6 debate on Brown 's nomination opened with Republicans praising Brown 's great talent while Democrats deemed Brown 's an extreme conservative ideologue . On June 8 , 10 Democrats joined Republicans to close debate and Senate voted 56 - 43 to confirm Brown 's . Just prior to the successful May 24 , 2005 cloture vote for the first judicial nominee under Senate consideration ( Pricilla Owen for U.S. Appeals Court 5th Circuit ) 14 moderate senators confirmed 14 moderate senators mutual pact to : vote for cloture in judicial confirmations , except in & quot;extraordinary circumstances&quot ; ; not change filibuster rules ; and vote for cloture for three less contentious federal judicial nominees , including Brown and the first judicial nominee under Senate consideration ( Pricilla Owen for U.S. Appeals Court 5th Circuit . On June 6 , Senate opened debate on Brown 's confirmation . On June 7 , 10 Democrats joined in the successful vote for cloture for Brown 's . On June 8 , Senate approved Brown 's nomination by 56 - 43 . Averting a showdown , Senate Democrats and Republicans finally reached a compromise which cleared the way for confirmation votes on Brown 's nomination . After stalling Brown 's nomination with a 2 - year filibuster threat , Democrats agreed to vote for cloture , ending debate on Brown 's confirmation . Republicans agreed not to force a change in the application of Senate filibuster rules by the so - called nuclear option . On June 8 , Brown 's won confirmation .
