summary: North Korea withdrew from the Nuclear Non - Proliferation Treaty and is in a standoff with six other nations . North Korea position is that nuclear weapons are needed for North Korea defense . The negotiations with South Korea , Japan , China , Russia , the UK and the US to persuade North Korea to cease North Korea nuclear weapons programs are continuing without much progress . North Korea demands to be treated as a nuclear power and for disarmament talks to apply to all countries involved . South Korea has proposed that the international community aid North Korea economically and institute a rehabilitation program once the nuclear issue is resolved . In February 2005 North Korea declared North Korea manufactured nuclear weapons and wo n't rejoin six other nations . In May the IAEA reported North Korea had close to six nuclear weapons . North Korea and S.K. resumed direct talks . In July North Korea returned to six - nation talks after the US recognized North Korea sovereignty . S.K. offered North Korea food , electricity , APEC membership , a multinational rehabilitation fund , and to establish a Northeast Asian Development Bank , if North Korea abandons nuclear weapons , which the US called & quot;premature&quot ; . North Korea said North Korea would return to the Nuclear Non - Proliferation Treaty , after its nuclear weapons programs was resolved . North Korea withdrew from the Nuclear Non - Proliferation Treaty after the US accused North Korea of having a nuclear weapons program based on enriched uranium . North Korea declared in February 2005 that North Korea has already built nuclear bombs . Since 2003 , six other nations have aimed at persuading North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons programs in exchange for diplomatic and economic benefits and security guarantees . Several rounds of six - party tallks on its nuclear weapons programs have broken down since August 2003 without an agreement . South Korea , the US , Japan , China , and Russia want North Korea to abandon North Korea development of nuclear weapons . North Korea insists on having nuclear power for peaceful purposes , something opposed by the US South Korea has promised massive aid to North Korea , including electricity , rice , and other necessities , if an agreement can be reached within the six - party framework . South Korea has also suggested a rehabilitation program for the North , suggested .

summary: Talks with North Korea reconvened following a five - week break . The U.S. and North Korea remain at a stalemate on the nuclear weapons program . A joint statement was signed with North Korea agreeing to rejoin the Treaty , to permit international inspectors , and to discontinue the nuclear weapons program . No timetable was determined . The international community promised to provide aid , security , energy assistance and work towards improving relations . The day after signing A joint statement North Korea reversed North Korea decision to cease the nuclear weapons program until North Korea receive a light - water reactor to create electricity . The September 19 , 2005 six - nations agreement included : North Korea giving up the nuclear weapons program ; returning to the NPT and IAEA safeguards ; The U.S. declared no nuclear arms on the Korean Peninsula and no intention to attack North Korea ; S.K. reaffirmed S.K. does n't have and wo n't deploy nuclear weapons ; China , Russia , S.K. , The U.S. and Japan agreed give North Korea a light - water reactor ; The U.S. and North Korea pledge to respect each other 's sovereignty , coexist peacefully , and normalize relations ; North Korea and Japan agreed to normalize ties ; China , Russia , S.K. , Japan and The U.S. gave North Korea energy assistance . Australia offered North Korea energy , aid and expertise . Talks with North Korea end with the signing of A joint statement . A joint statement states that North Korea agrees to abandon the nuclear weapons program and return to the Treaty in return for recognition of North Korea right to nuclear energy . North Korea also agrees to submit to International Atomic Energy safeguards . China , Russia , South Korea , Japan and the US give North Korea energy assistance and agree to discuss giving a light - water nuclear reactor for generating electricity . North Korea wo n't dismantle the nuclear weapons program until North Korea receives a light - water nuclear reactor for generating electricity . The six - party talks aimed at getting North Korea to abandon the nuclear weapons program resumed 13 - 19 September . North Korea pledged to abandon the nuclear weapons program , to rejoin the Treaty , and to follow IAEA safeguards in return for a pledge of aid and security . The U.S. agreed not to attack North Korea . China , Russia , South Korea , The U.S. , and Japan agreed to give North Korea energy assistance including a light - water reactor . But agreed fell apart almost immediately , when North Korea insisted that North Korea would not dismantle North Korea nuclear weapons program until a light - water reactor was built .

summary: On August 23 , 2005 the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe charged that Lance Armstrong used the drug EPO in 1999 . Lance Armstrong strongly denied charged . The French sports minister , the Tour de France director and the chief executive of the USCycling said that since the tests used as a basis for charged were inadequate no action would be taken against Lance Armstrong . A Texas scientist attributed Lance Armstrong performance to Lance Armstrong modern training approach , not the drug EPO . A specialist in the fight against doping in sports , however , suggested that Lance Armstrong had used a range of banned substances . On May 23 , 2005 the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe reported Lance Armstrong illegally used erythropoietin for Tour de France , based on urine samples examined outside World Anti - Doping Agency protocols , but linked to Lance Armstrong by L'Equip , in violation of WADA anonymity rules . Tour Director Leblanc accepted charged uncritically , but discipline seemed unlikely because WADA testing was impossible . The French sports minister agreed . USA Cycling , Miguel Indurain , and Ed Coyle defended Lance Armstrong . Lance Armstrong took erythropoietin during cancer treatments before 1999 . An International Cycling Union investigation of 1999 drug testing is pending . Alessandro Donati suggested without evidence that Lance Armstrong used other banned substances . the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe reported new tests by a French laboratory on backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at Tour de France tested positive for the drug EPO . Lance Armstrong strongly denied charged and questioned the validity of new tests by a French laboratory on backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at the 1999 Tour de France . USA Cycling , fellow cyclists , scientists and French fans have defended Lance Armstrong . Defenders attacked reported as unethical and the laboratory results as flawed and unsound . Lance Armstrong is suing a British newspaper for printing excerpts from a book which insinuated Lance Armstrong had been doping . An Italian specialist believes Lance Armstrong used other drugs , too . However , Lance Armstrong has never been found guilty of doping . the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe charged Lance Armstrong of using the drug EPO in 1999 to win Lance Armstrong first of seven consecutive Tours . The laboratory conducting new tests by a French laboratory on backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at the 1999 Tour de France could n't confirm backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at the 1999 Tour de France were Lance Armstrong , but the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe said the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe decoded the labels from samples identifying Lance Armstrong . Lance Armstrong strongly denies charged . The director of UT 's Human Performance Laboratory , who studied Lance Armstrong physiology from 1992 to 1999 , stated that Lance Armstrong record winning streak is explained by Lance Armstrong years of training and a modest diet in the spring months before Tour de France .

summary: On Sept. 9 , 2005 the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) said no action would be taken against Armstrong . On Sept. 21 the IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports demanded suspension of the French laboratory that accused Armstrong , claiming that the French laboratory that accused Armstrong tests were illegal . claiming was made in a letter to the World Anti - Doping Agency President , who replied that the French laboratory that accused Armstrong did not appear to have broken any ethical rules . On Oct. 6 the UCI President called for an independent investigator to look into the Armstrong matter in case ongoing investigations by UCI and World Anti - Doping Agency reached different conclusions . Armstrong sued SCA Promotions for breach of contract based on L'Equip 's charges . the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) Verbruggen refuted World Anti - Doping Agency Pound 's claims ICU 's Verbruggen gave L'Equip information linking Armstrong to positive 1999 erythropoietin results . ICU 's Verbruggen claimed WADA 's Pound 's blocked the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) investigation and made & quot;transparently erroneous statements&quot ; . the IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports both demanded World Anti - Doping Agency lab be suspended for illegally violating World Anti - Doping Agency code . UCI and WADA each appointed independent investigators into all issues relating to the Tour 's 1999 positive tests . Armstrong continues to vehemently deny doping charges . the UCI President called for an independent investigation into allegations Armstrong used EPO in 1999 . the UCI President questioned the integrity and validity of its tests and demanded the French laboratory that accused Armstrong be suspended . the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) and World Anti - Doping Agency both announced separate inquiries . UCI and WADA have been feuding over the case . UCI accused World Anti - Doping Agency of withholding information . World Anti - Doping Agency accused ICU 's Verbruggen of leaking documents to L'Equip . the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) gave Armstrong major support in Armstrong fight against doping allegations . An the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) statement said no action would be taken against Armstrong over claims that Armstrong 1999 urine samples tested positive for EPO . the International Cycling Union ( UCI ) found no wrongdoing and no reason to condemn Armstrong . the IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports have demanded the French laboratory that accused Armstrong be suspended . World Anti - Doping Agency insists the French laboratory that accused Armstrong broke a host of rules set down by WADA code .

summary: U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband were shot at U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's home in an apparent retaliation for U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's contempt order against Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements . Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements is currently in federal prison awaiting sentencing for previously soliciting the murder of U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's . Federal agents and police are investigating Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements colleagues and looking for two men seen near her home at the time of the murders . Evidence recovered at the scene include : shell casings , a fingerprint , footprint , and cigarette butts . Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements denies any involvement in the murders . U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband were murdered in U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband home on February 28 . U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband died of multiple gunshot wounds between 10:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. Evidence being analyzed includes broken window glass with a fingerprint , a bloody footprint , .22 - caliber shell casings , a bloody mop and cigarette butts . Investigators released composite sketches of two men seen near Lefkow 's home at the time of the murders . A $ 50,000 reward is being offered for leads in the case . The prime suspect is Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements . Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements and Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements supporters deny any involvement . Once Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements was convicted and in jail for plotting to the murder of Lefkow U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's , U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's security detail was dropped . Killers entered her home , had U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband lie on the basement floor , and shot each to death . Police and FBI investigated widely but focused on Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements and his supporters . Evidence included a window shard with a fingerprint , a bloody mop and shoeprint , cigarette butts , and 22 - caliber shell casings . Witness sightings of two white men waiting in a red Ford Escort produced composite sketches . Investigators seized communication and computer records and offered a $ 50,000 reward . U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow 's mother and husband were killed in the basement of her home on February 28 . Investigators found a bloody footprint and fingerprints butts at the scene . There are no suspects . Investigators have questioned relatives , friends , and supporters of Matthew Hale , a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements . Investigators also want to question two men seen in a car illegally parked near her home that afternoon . A $ 50,000 reward has been offered for information in the case .

summary: The Lefkow murder investigation continues . FBI Director Mueller testified to lawmakers that The Lefkow murder investigation will be solved . Bart Ross confessed to the Lefkow murders in Bart Ross suicide note . Several years ago Lefkow had dismissed Bart Ross billion dollar medical malpractice suit . DNA evidence gathered at the murder scene matched Bart Ross DNA . Gun shells found at the murder scene along with his suicide note point to Bart Ross as the likely killer . No evidence has been found linking Bart Ross to the Hale supremacist group . Authorities will not close The Lefkow murder investigation before ballistic results are completed . The Lefkow murder investigation took a surprising turn when Bart Ross committed suicide at a traffic stop on March 9 , leaving confessed in Bart Ross car . Later that day , a local TV station receive a typed suicide letter , dated February 13 , which included a hit list of judges , lawyers and doctors and a handwritten account of the Lefkow murders . Bart Ross felt Bart Ross was a medical malpractice victim and spent over a decade unsuccessfully pursuing lawsuits . Lefkow , was Bart Ross primary target March 9 . DNA evidence confirm Bart Ross was the killer . Bart Ross , 57 , was pulled over by police in a Milwaukee suburb for a defective taillight . Bart Ross immediately committed committed with a shot to Bart Ross head . In Bart Ross van was a letter describing how after treatment for mouth cancer left Bart Ross disfigured , Lefkow and others ruined Bart Ross life by dismissing Ross ' billion dollar medical malpractice suit . Bart Ross vowed to kill Judge Lefkow and others . On February 28th Bart Ross hid in a Lefkow closet waiting for Lefkow , but Lefkow family found Bart Ross first so Bart Ross killed her family instead . DNA from a cigarette butt in the home matched Bart Ross and Bart Ross resembled a composite sketch . Bart Ross , killed Bart Ross on March 9 with a single shot to his head when Bart Ross was stopped for a routine traffic violation . In his van was a typed suicide letter , dated February 13 , which included a hit list of judges , lawyers and doctors and a handwritten account of the Lefkow killings . Bart Ross had pursued a decade - long malpractice suit over severe disfigurement resulting from treatment for a cancerous jaw , a suit Lefkow had dismissed a number of years ago . Bart Ross wrote that Lefkow was & quot;No . 1 to kill&quot ; because Lefkow had & quot;finished Bart Ross off.&quot ; Bart Ross had a hit list of 25 other judges , lawyers , and doctors .

summary: Rioting by young Muslim men broke out in a Paris suburb on the night of Oct. 27 , 2005 . Cars were torched , windows smashed , and policemen stoned . On successive nights Rioting by young Muslim men spread to other parts of Paris and then to other cities . Thousands of police have been deployed to little avail . Fortunately casualties have been light . Some rioters blame Rioting by young Muslim men on tough policing policies but Rioting by young Muslim men is more likely caused by frustration of young men who have no work and little hope for the future . On Nov. 8 the French government authorized local authorities to impose curfews . On Oct. 27 , 2005 in a Paris suburb , two youth were electrocuted and one injured hiding in a power substation from police . For 12 days riots reached nearly 300 towns and urban Paris . A a Paris suburb mosque was tear gassed . Buildings were vandalized or firebombed . Paris airport trains halted . Thousands of riot police used tear gas and rubber bullets . A woman was torched . A beaten man died . Over 30 police and firemen were injured , two shot . Nationwide , the nights of November 4 - 7 saw 750 , 1,295 , 1,408 , and 1,173 torched vehicles ; 200 , 312 , 395 , and 330 arrests . Bloggers incited violence . Riots erupted after the accidental electrocution deaths of two youth . the accidental electrocution deaths of two youths hiding from police they mistakenly thought were pursuing them sparked an ever - escalating 12 nights of violence which spread through Paris suburbs and into Paris . Rioters torched hundreds of cars nightly , burned and vandalized buildings , injured dozens of police officers and firefighters , set a handicapped woman afire and beat a man to death . French officials appealed for calm and eventually imposed curfews to restore order . Rioters are French - Arab and French - African young men , frustrated by economic misery and racial discrimination and stigmatized by a new tough anti - crime initiative . Riots have raged for a dozen days in a Paris suburb . Rioters , have burned hundreds of cars and attacked firefighters and policemen . Police have made hundreds of arrests . Riots started after two youth were electrocuted when two youth scaled an electrical relay station wall while fleeing police and touched a transformer . Tough anti - crime policies of Interior Minister Nicholas Sarkozy fueled Riots . A man died after a beating and a woman was badly burned when exiting a bus . Police and firefighters have sustained minor injuries .

summary: On the night of Nov. 9 , 2005 the level of violence throughout France showed the first signs of abating . More than 11,500 police and gendarmes in 300 cities and towns had been mobilized . Residents , police and firefighters suffered one death and more than 115 injuries . More than 7500 vehicles were torched . Although the riots were ignited by the accidental electrocution death of two teenagers , President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront inequalities and discrimination among France African and Muslim minorities that fueled the riots . On Nov. 14 emergency powers were extended for three months . After long police absence , Sarkozy 's October 19 declaration of & quot;war without mercy&quot ; on violent suburbs fueled the riots . On November 8 , France declared a state of emergency , and offered social assistance . By November 11 , 118 residents , police , firefighters , and foreign journalists were injured , with $ US 235 million total damage . By November 13 , torched vehicles exceeded 8,000 and arrests exceeded 2,200 . Vehicle torchings and arrests , respectively , November 1 - 12 were : 180/34 , ? / ? , 517/78 , 897/250 , 1300/349 , 1408/395 , 1173/330 , 617/ ? , 482/ ? , 325/ ? , 384/162 , 315/161 . ( Before the riots , 3,500 vehicles burned monthly nationwide . ) France extended emergency powers on Nov. 14 . With a state of emergency declaration , overnight curfews , and a public meetings ban , violent riots around Paris and throughout France steadily abated . The situation markedly improved by the 18th night . The French cabinet extended emergency police powers for three months to ensure an end to the riots . Some 300 towns and cities were affected and around 11,500 anti - riot forces were mobilized . Damages and casualties were considerable . Over 115 citizens , police officers and firefighters were injured , as were three foreign reporters . A rioter lost a hand throwing a Molotov cocktail . Over 7,500 vehicles were torched and dozens of buildings destroyed . Rioting and unrest spread to some 300 areas across France . The government declared a state of emergency but left it to local authorities to enact curfews or other measures . Many areas did impose curfews but Paris only banned public meetings . Police were mobilized and made hundreds of arrests . Most rioters are young Arab and black residents who complain of economic misery and discrimination . Most rioters burned hundreds of vehicles and other acts of arson . President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront the inequalities and discrimination that fueled the riots . For years , police had warned that immigrant - dominated slums were about to explode .

summary: A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners became trapped for 3 days on the sea floor in eastern Russia . A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners was entangled in fishing nets and/or a coastal monitoring system antenna . Russian rescue attempts to free and raise A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners were unsuccessful . Russia requested international help . Japan , Britain and the U.S. responded with rescue equipment . The British Navy used a robotic vehicle to free the submarine which then surfaced . 7 submariners were in satisfactory condition and taken for medical examination . Russia naval equipment has not been upgraded as promised by Putin following the Kursk submarine tragedy . On Aug. 4 , 2005 Russia , working desperately to disengage A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners , called for international help . Japan dispatched four vessels , Britain Royal Navy sent a robotic vehicle and the U. S. Pacific fleet sent two vehicles similar to The British Navy . Estimates varied as to how much oxygen remained for 7 submariners . a robotic vehicle arrived first and on Aug. 7 A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners was cut loose and 7 submariners were found all alive . For nearly three days , A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners was trapped about 600 feet below the surface of the Beryozovaya Bay . The AS-28 became snarled in the cables of an undersea coastal monitoring system . Throughout the ordeal , there were varying estimates of the remaining oxygen supply . When Russian attempts to tow A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners to shallower water failed , Russia sent out an urgent call for international help . Japan , Britain and the U.S. dispatched vessels to aid the rescue efforts . a robotic vehicle succeeded in freeing A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners . 7 submariners were rescued in satisfactory condition . A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners was trapped on the seabed off the Kamchatka peninsula late on 4 August . Russia tried desperately to pull A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners to shallower waters but pull failed . Russia sought international assistance . Japan sent four vessels , the U.S. sent three underwater vehicles , but The British Navy were the first to arrive , with remote control submersibles . The British Navy cut away the net or undersea cables trapping A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners , enabling A Russian mini - submarine containing 7 submariners to rise to the surface after almost three days at the bottom . 7 submariners were alive and well .

summary: Criticism by Russian authorities of Russian authorities Navy arose quickly following the rescue . Accident notification was delayed as in the Kursk tragedy . Putin ordered an investigation . Russian rescuers damaged Russian rescuers underwater robotic vehicle during the rescue attempt making their underwater robotic vehicle inoperable . When the British rescue vehicle arrived by air there was no equipment to unload their underwater robotic vehicle . Russian authorities is considering purchasing a robotic Scorpio or Panther for underwater rescue operations . Adm. Kuroyedov , head of their Navy , was fired and replaced by Adm. Masorin . Adm. Masorin has been charged with improving their Navy . Operation errors by the crew were cited as causing the accident . Following recovery of the submarine , Russian authorities praised the rescue attempt and thanked Britain , the U.S. and Japan , but questions were soon raised as to why their Navy did not have the proper equipment for such an operation . Updated equipment was soon purchased . Putin ordered an investigation of the accident . On Sept. 4 Putin fired Adm. Kuroyedov , head of the Russian Navy . On Sept 6 the defense minister announced that the accident was a result of outrageous violations of the instructions by senior officials of the Russian Pacific Fleet and that the crew had made errors . An investigation uncovered violations of instructions and errors in operating the submarine that contributed to the accident . Prosecutors accused a naval officer of negligence for damaging the British rescue vehicle , thereby necessitating international assistance . Newspapers criticized their Navy for waiting over a day before revealing information about the accident . There are conflicting reports about whether the submarine was caught in cables or fishing nets . their Navy is considering buying at least one Scorpio and possibly a newer model Panther rescue vehicle . Adm. Kuroyedov , head of the Russian Navy was fired , probably in part because of the accident . Putin ordered the defense minister to launch an investigation . Adm. Kuroyedov , head of the Russian Navy was fired . A their Navy captain was accused of damaging a Russian under - water remote - controlled vehicle in rescue attempts . Five British , one Japanese , and two Americans were given state awards . the crew were given awards for bravery , but later accused of violating operating procedures and causing the submarine entanglement . their Navy was considering buying one or two submersible rescue vessels . the rescue cost Russian authorities an estimated $ 1.5 million . Britain , the U.S. , and Japan did not charge Russian authorities for Britain , the U.S. , and Japan assistance .

summary: During the morning rush hour on July 7 , terrorists exploded bombs on three London subway trains and a double - decker bus , killing at least 52 and injuring 700 . A group called Secret al - Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility . exploded were timed to coincide with the G-8 summit meeting at Gleneagles , Scotland . Forensic evidence indicates that each bomb contained less than 10 pounds of possibly military - grade high explosives , and all were made by a single bomb maker . There is not yet evidence as to whether suicide bombers were involved . Police are close to identifying someone responsible for the bus attack . exploded struck central London on July 7 , three in subway cars and one on a double - decker bus . exploded killed at least 52 and sent 350 to hospitals where 22 remain critical . An additional 350 were treated for light injuries . Hot , dusty conditions in subway tunnels hampered rescue operations . PM Tony Blair returned to London from the Group of Eight meeting in Scotland after exploded . Police said each bomb contained less than ten pounds of military - grade explosives and did not rule out suicide bombers as responsible . A group called Secret al - Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility . bombs exploded in central London during morning rush hour on July 7 , coinciding with the G-8 summit meeting at Gleneagles , Scotland . 700 were injured and at least 52 killed . bombs were on three London subway trains and one on a double - decker bus . Each was small enough to fit in a rucksack . A group called Secret al - Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility , to avenge British involvement in wars in Afghanistan and Iraq . No evidence arose of suicide bombers . Investigators viewed video by cameras on streets and subway platforms around London . Londoners took exploded in stride , used to IRA bombs and the WWII blitz . exploded occurred in London during the morning rush hour on July 7 . Bombs exploded on three London subway trains and a double - decker bus . exploded contained similar components : military - grade explosives under 10 pounds , small enough to fit into a backpack . exploded killed at least 52 and injured 700 . Investigations at the tunnel site were slow , hampered by very high heat , asbestos dust , and twisted metal . Investigators do not know how many suspects Investigators are looking for , but reported progress toward identifying one of the bombers .

summary: The July 7 London bombing death toll is now 56 , including four suicide bombers . Police identified four suicide bombers and know details of four suicide bombers final movements . four suicide bombers were British of Pakistani origin . Police raided five premises in Leeds and recovered a car Police expect will yield evidence . Authorities were tipped off when one bomber 's mother called a help line to report one bomber 's missing . ABC News reported that the alleged bomb maker behind the London attacks was arrested in Egypt . Authorities fear that a number of recent arson attacks on mosques in England may have been retaliation for the London attacks . The July 7 London bombing death toll rose to 56 and 44 victims of the London attacks remain in hospitals , nine in intensive care . four suicide bombers were four suicide bombers . Police identified three of four suicide bombers by name and said that four suicide bombers were British of Pakistani origin . Police were able to trace the movements on CCTV of four suicide bombers from four suicide bombers arrival at a carpark until just before the London attacks . Armed with warrants , police raided five premises in Leeds . four suicide bombers were British of Pakistani origin and were among the 56 killed . four suicide bombers left four suicide bombers homes in West Yorkshire and drove a rented a car to Luton , NW of London , where four suicide bombers met a fourth accomplice . Closed circuit television at King 's Cross caught them all chatting , then them all split up . one bomber 's mother reported one bomber 's missing after the London attacks , leading to identifications and raids on five premises in Leeds . the alleged bomb maker behind the London attacks was arrested in Egypt . After the London attacks , several arson attacks took place on mosques in northwest England . As of 20 July , The July 7 London bombing death toll stood at 56 , with the 56 killed identified . Police had finished Police investigations on site and moved one subway car from the underground tunnel to a police compound for further investigation . four suicide bombers , were Islamic extremists . British of Pakistani origin , four suicide bombers were captured on closed ciruit TV at King 's Cross soon before the London attacks . An additional suspect was said to have been arrested in Cairo , Egypt , on 15 July .

summary: Syria 's withdrawal of forces from Lebanon , required by UN Resolution 1559 , Sept. 2 , 2004 , was not satisfied by Syria 's proposal on Feb. 24 , 2005 to pull back into eastern Lebanon . The U.N. Chief , supported by Egypt , Saudi Arabia , the U.S. , France and Russia , called for full withdrawal . On March 5 the Syrian President promised pullback to the border . A top UN envoy on March 12 demanded a full withdrawal by April 30 , a position supported by the European Union . By April 26 full withdrawal was under way and UN had sent a team to verify whether full withdrawal was complete . UN Resolution 1559 , Sept. 2 , 2004 mandated withdrawal of & quot;foreign forces&quot ; ( Syria 's troops and intelligence agents ) from Lebanon . After the February 14 , 2005 assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri , Anon told Syria 's to withdraw before April , threatening sanctions . Egypt and Saudi Arabia asked Syria 's to withdraw by April 30 , under the 1989 Taif Accord . Lebanon pro - Syria 's government resigned March 1 . On March 12 Anon sent envoy Roed - Larsen to Syria 's with an ultimatum . Syria 's pledged to withdraw all troops . Syria 's Foreign Ministers asked Syria 's to rapidly implement pledged . The February assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri put Syria 's under renewed pressure from the international community to abide by UN Resolution 1559 , Sept. 2 , 2004 and withdraw Syria 's troops from Lebanon . The US , France and other European Union nations urged Syria 's to comply . Egypt and Saudi Arabia encouraged Syria 's to withdraw its troops by the UN deadline of April 30 . Faced with a UN ultimatum , on April 3 Syria 's pledged to remove all troops and intelligence agents by April 30 . UN sent a team of inspectors to verify whether full withdrawal was complete at the end of April 30 . The February assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri renewed calls for Syria 's to abide by UN Resolution 1559 , Sept. 2 , 2004 and end Syria 's domination of Lebanon . Nine council members voted for UN Resolution 1559 , Sept. 2 , 2004 , six abstained . Egypt and Saudi Arabia are trying to persuade Syria 's to accept a timetable for withdrawal of its troops . The US and France have been leading calls for withdrawal of its troops . the European Union called for a precise timetable for withdrawal . UN Secretary - General Kofi Annan said that full withdrawal must be handled with care . Under mounting pressure , Syria 's has withdrawn 4,000 of its troops .

summary: On May 5 UN Chief Kofi Anan announced that the UN team had verified that all Syrian troops and intelligence officials had left Lebanon , but it was reported that the UN team could not be certain about the intelligence operatives . There were reports that some remained with a hit list of planned assassinations . Syria denied the accusations . The UN envoy had & quot;constructive and helpful&quot ; talks with the Syrian president on June 12 . One June 23 , as another UN verification team investigated , US officials expressed certainty that Syrian military intelligence operatives remained in Lebanon . By May 23 , 2005 , a UN team verified the pullout of all Syrian troops and intelligence officials from Lebanon . In June , the Syrian president warned Syria to withdraw Syria remaining intelligence agents in Lebanon . Syria denied having any intelligence agents in Lebanon . a UN team went back to Lebanon to ascertain the facts . UN said UN was encouraged by talks with Syria President regarding evidence from several countries that Syrian intelligence agents were still in Lebanon . Egypt and Saudi Arabia discussed the Syria - Lebanon situation . The U.S. reiterated The U.S. certainty that Syrian intelligence agents remained in Lebanon . Although a U.N. team verified the pullout of all Syrian troops and intelligence agents from Lebanon , the US and Lebanese opposition leaders insisted that Syrian intelligence agents remained in Lebanon . The killing of a prominent anti - Syrian journalist aroused suspicions that Syria had a hit list targeting opposition leaders . Syria rejected all accusations . the Syrian president issued a new warning to Syria to withdraw intelligence forces . U.N. was encouraged by talks with Syria on the Security Council call for Syria to end Syria involvement in Lebanon . A U.N. verification team was sent to Lebanon by late June to investigate . a UN team verified the pullout of all Syrian troops and intelligence agents from Lebanon . International pressure following the assassination of Raafik Hariri was more of a factor leading to the pullout of all Syrian troops and intelligence agents from Lebanon than the UN resolution . A Lebanese Druse leader claimed that Syrian military intelligence was still operating in Lebanon and feared more assassinations after a bombing killed an anti - Syrian journalist . These reports caused the Syrian president to warn Syria to withdraw Syria forces from Lebanon . Syria claimed that every troop and agent had left Lebanon . UN ordered a verification mission back to Lebanon .

summary: The Ukrainian presidential election race to replace President Kuchma is close and competitive . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - President Kuchma opposition has a small lead over Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and President Kuchma supporter . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition became dangerously ill during the campaign claiming an assassination attempt . No evidence of poisoning has been found by Ukrainian or U.S. investigations . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition won the first vote but Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter was declared President after a disputed runoff vote . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition demanded the results be annulled . Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter offered Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition the prime ministry but Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition refused and called for both candidates to withdraw from The Ukrainian presidential election race to replace President Kuchma . In the campaign , Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition claimed Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition was poisoned by supporters of Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter . International observers alleged election violations . Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter moved the Kiev Liberation Day military parade to October 29 , raising fears of a military crackdown or canceled elections . State media denied Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition any coverage . Students and public employees were pressured to vote for Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter . Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter raised pensions before the elections . On October 31 , Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition got 39.82 % , Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter 39.32 % . An emergency Parliament meeting without a quorum reversed Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter November 21 victory . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition proposed new elections . Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter offered Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition the Prime Ministry . the elections reduced the candidates from 24 to two , both candidates . the results are being disputed . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition is claiming Yanukovich 's November 21 victory is the result of an illegal electoral commission decision and is demanding the results be annulled . While campaigning , Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition was struck by a mysterious illness in September and spent most of the month in an Austrian hospital . Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition and Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition supporters believe Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition was poisoned by political rivals . Doctors are still examining blood and other samples to determine the cause . Doctors expect Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition to make a full recovery . Ukrainian presidential elections were extremely close between both candidates . Runoff elections on 21 November resulted in a standoff , with Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition refusing to recognize Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter as President and calling for new elections , and with Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter saying that Viktor Yanukovich , current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter would appoint Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition Prime Minister . In September Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition was treated in Vienna for a mysterious illness . Supporters claimed that the illness , which occurred after a meeting with Viktor Yushchenko , former Prime Minister and leader of the anti - Kuchma opposition , was an assassination attempt . Doctors said that Doctors did not know the cause .

summary: Specialists in several countries confirmed that Viktor Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with pure TCDD , a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues . The poisoning investigation is ongoing . The earlier disputed presidential election was declared fraudulent and invalid by the Supreme Court . A repeat election was mandated . Foreign observers will help secure an honest election . Viktor Yushchenko was elected president of the Ukraine with 51.99 percent of the vote . As Viktor Yushchenko took the oath of office Viktor Yushchenko vowed to improve economic conditions in the Ukraine . Viktor Yanukovych vowed to appeal the election results to the Supreme Court . the Supreme Court invalidated The earlier disputed presidential election , due to election fraud . Viktor Yushchenko ingested poison was identified as pure TCDD , a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues . Viktor Yushchenko deferred criminal investigations until after A repeat election . Parliament failed to pass Viktor Yushchenko election reforms , but the Constitutional Court ruled for expanded home voting , which helped Viktor Yushchenko . Viktor Yushchenko supporters pushed for Viktor Yanukovych resignation ; instead Viktor Yanukovych took a leave of absence to run Viktor Yushchenko campaign . Viktor Yushchenko won the Presidency 51.99 % to 44.20 % for Viktor Yanukovych . Viktor Yanukovych said Viktor Yanukovych would appeal to the Supreme Court , without much hope . In December , doctors determined conclusively that Viktor Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with pure TCDD , a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues . Prosecutors reopened a criminal investigation into Viktor Yushchenko attempted murder . Viktor Yushchenko was sure that Ukrainian authorities were responsible . Viktor Yushchenko fell ill on September 6 , after having food and drinks with the head of the Security Service of the Ukraine and others . the Supreme Court overturned The earlier disputed presidential election due to fraud , and Parliament enacted new anti - fraud election reforms in December . Viktor Yushchenko won A repeat election on December 26 and took office in January , Viktor Yushchenko face still disfigured by pure TCDD , a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues . Viktor Yushchenko was sworn in as president of the Ukraine on Sunday 23 January . In a third round of voting on December 26 , Viktor Yushchenko won 51.99 % of the vote to Viktor Yanukovych 44.20 % . the Supreme Court had annulled the election results of the second round of voting because of election fraud . won followed 17 days of massive popular protests called the & quot;Orange Revolution&quot ; after Viktor Yushchenko campaign color . Doctors confirmed that Viktor Yushchenko had been deliberately poisoned with TCDD , the most lethal form of dioxin . Blood tests revealed levels of dioxin & quot;more than 1000 times&quot ; normal . Viktor Yushchenko will need treatment for months if not years .

summary: New drug SR-13668 curbs AKT retroviral oncogene proteins for breast cancer . SR-16158 also treats breast cancer . The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences ' Sisters Study for breast cancer compares shared genes . Arimidex and Aromasin appear to sharply reduce breast cancer occurrence or metastasis . Oleic acid dramatically cuts expression of breast cancer precursor gene Her-2 / neu and amplifies Herceptin . DNA repair deficiency strongly associates with susceptibility to breast cancer . Hypothyroidism apparently lessens chances of developing aggressive forms of breast cancer . Modern radiation therapy likely does not increase heart disease risk . Oral contraceptives likely do not increase the risk of BRAC1 - associated breast cancer . The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences ' and a pharmaceutical company are testing two medications that can treat breast cancer . One drug can curb a protein active in cancer patients and the other is less likely to trigger cardiovascular disease . A new U.S. Sister Study will investigate genetic and environmental causes of breast cancer . A new drug , aromatase inhibitor , appears to sharply reduce the chances of developing cancer in the other breast . Researchers say that olive oil may help fight breast cancer . Oral contraceptives may reduce the risk of breast cancer in high - risk groups . Developmental drug SR-13668 curbs a protein active in cancer patients ; and SR-16158 reduces breast cancer patient heart disease risk . Aromatase inhibitors lessen breast cancer recurrence with fewer side effects than tamoxifen . Radiation therapy no longer carries heart disease risk . Olive oil suppresses breast cancer precursor gene Her-2 / neu and boosts effectiveness of Herceptin . Hypothyroidism and oral contraceptives reduce breast cancer risk . Sisters are being studied to investigate environmental and genetic affects on cancer risk . Deficiency in cell DNA repair - ability accelerates genetic changes leading to cancer . Protein markers in genes help predict cancer recurrence . Ductal lavage proved unreliable for detecting early cancer . An international group is studying an aromatose inhibitor , which may replace tamoxifen . And a Taiwanese - U.S. cooperative effort is developing a new breast - cancer drug . The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences ' has undertaken a study of sisters to find genetic and environmental causes of the disease . Other studies are looking into the effects and effectiveness of oral contraceptives , an underactive thyroid , olive oil , a cell 's ability to repair DNA , and the flushing of milk ducts . A new Dutch diagnostic tool could help some breast - cancer patients avoid unnecessary treatment . And advances in technology and techniques have now made radiation safe for breast - cancer patients .

summary: Herceptin reduced HER2 - positive gene - associated breast cancer recurrences 52 percent . Avastin proved effective against breast cancer . Low - grade ductal carcinoma in situ becomes invasive cancer in 40 percent of patients over 40 years . Combined chemotherapy and hormone therapy cut death in half within 15 years from recurring breast cancer . Consuming 33.3 fat grams daily reduces breast cancer recurrence 30 % over five years . Exercise increases breast cancer survival 50 % . Low melatonin levels in night - time workers increased breast cancer . Benign & quot;proliferative&quot ; lesions correlate with later breast cancer . At 65 and older , early smaller localized tumors accounted for 96 % of survival improvement ; 38 % under 50 . Herceptin will soon be added to chemotherapy as a standard part of post surgical treatment for some breast cancer patients . Scientists reported that breast cancer patients who follow diets low in fat might reduce the chance that breast cancer patients who follow diets low in fat tumors will return . A study showed that walking for three to five hours per week reduced the risk of death by 50 percent . Another study examining the role of childhood diet plays in breast cancer found an association between eating French fries regularly during the preschool years and developing breast cancer as an adult . Risk of dying from breast cancer fell because drugs prevent recurrence and earlier - detected tumors are smaller . Herceptin halves risk of recurrence in women with tumors high in protein HER2 . A low - fat diet and exercise may reduce chances of recurrence . Only removing the lymph node nearest a cancer is less invasive and accurately detects whether cancer has spread . Low - grade ductal carcinoma in situ has various grades , can be mistaken as benign , and can take 40 years to develop . Night shift workers , women with benign breast lesions , and girls who frequently ate French fries as preschoolers have a higher risk of breast cancer . Breast cancer survival rates have improved because of better screening , leading to detection of smaller tumors when Breast cancer is still localized . There are two new drugs for breast cancer - Herceptin and avastin . Scientists see a link between benign breast cancer lesions and later cancer . Studies have shown that both low - fat diets and exercise can increase survival rates for breast cancer patients . But eating french fries in childhood can lead to cancer in adulthood . Night workers seem to have a higher incidence of breast cancer , indicating that there may be a relationship between tumor developent and exposure to light .

summary: In response to a call from the Institute of Medicine for a program against childhood obesity , there has been some action . One children 's TV network introduced a Saturday afternoon message encouraging children to go out and play . Some schools have expanded physical education programs , yanked junk foods from vending machines and reduced fat in cafeteria food . At least one YMCA has introduced a fitness room designed for pre - teens . Congress has considered legislation to control advertising to children and Kraft Foods promised to stop TV advertising of certain products considered unhealthy to children under 12 . To combat childhood obesity in the US , schools are removing unhealthy food from vending machines , reducing the fat in lunches , and requiring more physical education . New Hampshire is instituting twice - yearly weigh - ins for students . Children 's hospitals have weight management programs and a YMCA has a kid - friendly fitness room . Efforts are being made to regulate advertising to young children . Manufacturers offer cereals low in sugar and salt with more vitamins and whole grains . US Cabinet secretaries and children 's television networks are promoting healthier lifestyles for children . In New Zealand , schools added a mandatory extra hour of physical activity for students every week . Scientists say reversing childhood obesity requires wide - ranging efforts . Less time should be spent in front of the computer and television . Schools should remove junk food from vending machines and reduce the fat in cafeteria lunches . Experts recommend reducing sugar consumption . Changes need to be made in food labeling and advertising as well as more school and community recreational facilities and physical education programs . Trainers can help kids who do n't enjoy organized sports or who are embarrassed doing active things with fitter kids . Measures to fight childhood obesity include less time at the TV and computer , changes in food labeling and advertising , more school and community physical education programs and education to help children make better choices . One children 's TV network is encouraging children to go outside and play . One children 's TV network have also awarded grants to schools to expand physical play . Kraft Foods will stop TV ads of products unhealthy for children . New Zealand has ordered schools to ensure children take extra physical education . Schools in New Hampshire and Rhode Island have removed junk food and reduced fat in cafeteria lunches .

summary: On May 3 , 2005 former President Bill Clinton announced a partnership of the American Heart Association with the food and restaurant industry to increase physical activity and nutrition at schools nationwide . Other action against childhood obesity followed in August and September as the American Beverage Association agreed to limit distribution of high caloric beverages in schools and Kraft unveiled new whole grain versions of some of the most popular cookies . It was announced in Bangkok , Thailand that fresh fruits , fruit juices and fresh milk would replace sweet and fatty foods in 433 schools across Bangkok , Thailand . former President Bill Clinton launched a 10 - year initiative to combat childhood obesity . The initiative , a partnership with the American Heart Association , will include working with the food and restaurant industry to promote change , increasing physical activity and improved nutrition at schools nationwide . School systems are now limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children and requiring more fruits and vegetables in school meals . McDonald 's has made a major marketing shift toward promoting healthier eating habits . Kraft has developed whole - grain versions of two of Kraft popular cookies . Abroad , schools in Bangkok , Thailand are banning sugary and fatty foods and drinks . Dr. George Bray , founding president of the North American Association for the Study of Obesity , warns that high - fructose corn syrup is a strong culprit behind childhood obesity . Dr. George Bray , founding president of the North American Association for the Study of Obesity suggests that childhood obesity can be prevented by getting more sleep , decreasing sedentary activities , drinking more milk ( calcium controls weight ) , thinking portion control and eating breakfast . An Institute of Medicine report found compelling evidence encouraging the food industry to change the nature of foods being marketed to children . former President Bill Clinton announced a 10 - year initiative to combat childhood obesity . Illinois is now the only state that requires daily physical activity for public school students but Texas is proposing bills to require daily physical activity for public school students . former President Bill Clinton former President Bill Clinton partnered with the American Heart Association to promote physical activity at schools nationwide . Many schools are limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children . California has taken the lead in purging soda and unhealthy snacks from schools . McDonald 's has made a major shift in marketing that could help redefine fast food . Kraft now produces a healthier cookie made with whole grains and containing zero grams of trans fats .

summary: Investigations of lobbyist Jack Abramoff and lobbyist Jack Abramoff partner Michael Scanlon by the Senate Indian Affairs Committee in 2004 resulted in other investigations . lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his partner Michael Scanlon lobbying for Indian tribes and Pacific islanders was shown to have benefitted the lobbyists and political associates while bilking the clients of millions of dollars . The House majority leader and a congressman were implicated . On Nov. 18 , 2005 his partner Michael Scanlon was charged with fraud and scheduled to go to court on a conspiracy count contained in a criminal information , typically a prelude to pleading guilty and giving full cooperation with government investigators . lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his partner Michael Scanlon are at the center of a growing corruption scandal . a growing corruption scandal began with allegations of fraud in dealings with a number of American Indian tribes , but widened to include golf junkets and dealings in the Northern Marianas . a growing corruption scandal has focused attention on a number of members of Congress and members of Congress associates , including House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas and Rep. Robert Ney of Ohio . lobbyist Jack Abramoff has been arrested on fraud charges stemming from a Florida deal . his partner Michael Scanlon is expected to plead guilty to charges and cooperate with government investigators . the Senate Indian Affairs Committee charged lobbyist Jack Abramoff with running a crude extortion racket that has bilked tribes out of millions of dollars . House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas , additional congressmen and House aides are under an ethics investigation resulting from House Majority Leader Tom DeLay , additional congressmen and House aides connections with lobbyist Jack Abramoff . lobbyist Jack Abramoff activities in the Northern Marianas are also being investigated . lobbyist Jack Abramoff has been indicated in federal court on six counts of fraud and conspiracy and his partner Michael Scanlon was charged with defrauding Indian tribes of millions of dollars . lobbyist Jack Abramoff is being investigated in connection with manipulating elections and extorting lobbying fees of $ 66 million from six Indian tribes related to protecting gaming franchises , and $ 9 million from the Northern Marianas related to the textile industry . Investigations also involve lobbyist Jack Abramoff purchase of a gambling cruise ship company and arranging unreported golf junkets to Scotland . lobbyist Jack Abramoff invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Senate hearing . Also implicated are House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas , House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas former aide Michael Scanlon , Ralph Reed , Representative Robert W. Ney , and David Safavian . David Safavian was indicted in connection with a golf trip .

summary: Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe a congressman and other public officials . Scanlon help was expected to be crucial in the Justice Department 's wide - ranging Abramoff investigations . On Dec. 28 , 2005 the Justice Department 's was urgently pressing Abramoff to settle fraud and bribery allegations as the Justice Department 's wide - ranging Abramoff investigations continued . A court date was set for Jan. 9 , 2006 as Senate and criminal investigations continued . On Jan. 3 Abramoff pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate . Abramoff agreed to provide evidence and testimony in the Justice Department 's wide - ranging Abramoff investigations . Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe public officials and agreed to pay back over $ 19 million to Indian tribal clients . Scanlon possible 5 - year prison sentence could be reduced should Scanlon cooperate with prosecutors . Abramoff pleaded guilty to federal conspiracy , fraud and tax evasion charges and agreed to cooperate with investigators . Abramoff did not identify officials by name . The next day Abramoff pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy in Florida . Panicked lawmakers , including President Bush , rushed to distance Panicked lawmakers , including President Bush from Abramoff by returning campaign money Abramoff gave Panicked lawmakers , including President Bush . campaign money he gave them is being returned or redirected to charities . Abramoff pleaded guilty to conspiracy , fraud and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with federal officials investing political corruption . Abramoff is also facing trial on fraud charges in Florida connected with purchasing a casino cruise chip company . In agreed , Abramoff committed to making 25 million in restitution to Abramoff victims and paying 1.2 million to the IRS for tax evasion . Abramoff prison sentence could be lowered depending on assistance Abramoff provides in the Justice Department 's wide - ranging Abramoff investigations . Abramoff extensive corruption schemes are the subject of a Senate probe and criminal investigations by the Justice Department 's and Florida prosecutors . Investigators are looking at congressmen , aides , government officials , and lobbyists , including Rep. John Doolittle , Stephen Griles , and Tony Rudy , and will follow the case wherever the case leads . Scanlon pled guilty to bribery and agreed to make restitution to tribes . Scanlon help would be crucial to the Justice Department 's wide - ranging Abramoff investigations . Abramoff pled guilty to conspiracy , fraud , and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors . Co - defendant Adam Kidan agreed to testify against Abramoff regarding fraud in a ship company purchase .

summary: Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama is the most costly natural disaster in U.S. history . Initial insurance industry losses are estimated to be $ 20 billion . The Federal Emergency Management Agency expenses to date are almost $ 3 billion . The revised insurance losses estimate may be as high as $ 50 billion primarily due to damage of offshore energy sites . A Bush - Clinton Katrina Fund led by the former U.S. Presidents is accepting international donations . Qatar and Uganda have donated $ 100 million and $ 200,000 respectively . The current death count in the region is 126 . When Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama hit the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama on August 29 , 2005 rescue crews worked frantically to save hundreds of people trapped by floodwaters . By September 8 , the US death toll had reached 118 . There was one reported death in Guatemala . FEMA 's Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama disaster response efforts cost $ US 2.87 million as of September 6 , 2005 . By September 12 , Swiss Reinsurance Company , estimated $ US 40 billion global insured losses in the United States from Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama . The Emir of Qatar donated $ US 100 million for US victims of Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama . Uganda pledged $ US 200,000 toward Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama relief and rebuilding in the United States . Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama hit the southern part of the United States on August 29 , 2005 . the US death toll has risen to 118 . Federal Emergency Management Agency officials indicate that Federal Emergency Management Agency costs are 2.8 billion dollars so far . Qatar donated 100 million dollars to the victims and Uganda pledged 200,000 dollars toward relief and rebuilding efforts . Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama could cost the world 's insurers up to 50 billion dollars as forecast by the British company Brit Insurance . Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana , Mississippi and Alabama hit U.S. Gulf Coast on August 29 , 2005 . By 9 September the US death toll had reached 118 , including one Guatemalan woman who lived in New Orleans . Fifty other Guatemalans were missing . FEMA 's mission expenses were close to $ 3 billion as of 6 September . Insurers , inclduing Lloyd 's and Brit Insurance , estimated that Insurers , inclduing Lloyd 's and Brit Insurance , costs would reach $ 50 billion . Damage included offshore energy installations , as well as property damage and business interruption . Qatar was donating $ 100 million for the victims . Uganda had pladged $ 200,000 for relief and rebuilding .

summary: In addition to the current high death toll of 1,121 victims , the severe economic impacts are being assessed . Petroleum and chemicals produced in the Gulf region were sharply reduced as was oil and natural gas extraction . The 0.1 % rise was extremely below economic forecasts . Farming losses are expected to be $ 900 million . Part of the economic impact of Katrina is the unemployment rate in Louisiana which has risen to 11.5 % . The U.S. House of Representatives unanimously passed a $ 6.1 billion tax assistance package for people and businesses displaced due to Katrina and sent a $ 6.1 billion tax assistance package for people and businesses displaced due to Katrina to the U.S. Senate for consideration . By September 27 , 2005 US Katrina deaths reached 1,121 . Rescuers searched for victims as successor Hurricane Rita struck . By September 14 Brit Insurance forecast $ US 50 billion global insurance losses . the Gulf region oil and natural gas extraction dropped sharply . Refineries and chemical plants faltered . US Agriculture lost $ US 900 million . In September Louisiana unemployment was 11.5 % , from August 's 5.7 % . Turkey gave $ US 1.5 million to the US Red Cross for Katrina relief and $ US 1 million in humanitarian supplies . Bosnia 's Red Cross gave money . On September 21 , The U.S. House of Representatives passed $ US 6.1 billion in Katrina recovery tax breaks . The death toll from Katrina surpassed 1,100 . Turkey has allocated 2.5 million dollars for victims and Bosnia 's Red Cross announced that Bosnia 's Red Cross has started raising money for victims , as well . The U.S. House of Representatives approved tax breaks for victims . Katrina caused job losses in Louisiana sending Louisiana unemployment rate soaring to 11.5 percent . Agricultural losses are expected to reach an estimated 900 million dollars and US industrial output has been depressed by Katrina with severe cut backs in production of petroleum and chemicals . As of 29 September , Katrina death toll had reached 1121 including 885 in Louisiana and 200 in Mississippi . The economic impact was massive . The global insurance industry was predicting costs of $ 40-$50 billion . Agricultural losses were estimated at $ 900 million . its unemployment rate soared to 11.5 % . And U.S. industrial output rose only slightly because of cuts in the production of petroleum and chemicals in the Gulf region . 118 countries sent aid , including $ 2.5 million from Turkey . The U.S. Congress was expected to approve tax breaks of $ 6.1 billion for people and businesses .

summary: Martha Stewart reported to a federal prison in Alderson , West Virginia on Oct. 8 , 2004 to serve a five - month sentence . Martha Stewart is very busy . Being deluged with letters , Martha Stewart spends up to three hours / night at a prison typewriter . Martha Stewart has some duties such as cleaning toilets but is treated with respect and spends most of Martha Stewart time reading and making friends . Martha Stewart takes walks , goes to the gym and watches TV . Martha Stewart has one roommate and is working on innovative ways to do microwave cooking to share with inmates . Martha Stewart only real complaint is the & quot;terrible&quot ; food . Martha Stewart reported to a federal prison in Alderson , West Virginia on Oct. 8 , 2004 to begin serving a five - month sentence . Martha Stewart began a five - month sentence despite Martha Stewart pending appeal in order to sooner put Martha Stewart nightmare ordeal behind Martha Stewart and reclaim Martha Stewart good life . Martha Stewart arrived in good spirits and adjusted well . Prison officials and fellow inmates have been nice . Martha Stewart keeps busy performing chores , taking walks , exercising in the gym , reading , writing , watching television news , and creating innovative microwave recipes . Martha Stewart 's received thousands of letters from fans and has had visitors , including Martha Stewart daughter . Martha Stewart , will be serving a five - month sentence for lying to federal investigators about Martha Stewart suspiciously timed stock sale . In a web site letter , Martha Stewart says Martha Stewart is adjusting to life behind bars . Martha Stewart is spending time figuring out innovative way to do microwave cooking among other activities . Martha Stewart was touched by the outpouring of support Martha Stewart received from millions of people who visited Martha Stewart web site and urged fans to send donations to the American Cancer Society . Martha Stewart lawyer has filed her pending appeal . Martha Stewart arrived in good spirits for a five - month sentence . Martha Stewart was treated with respect and thought inmates and officials were all nice . Martha Stewart was issued clothing but could also wear an inexpensive watch and earrings . Martha Stewart had one roommate . Martha Stewart exercised , took walks , cleaned toilets , read , subscribed to newspapers , watched TV news , made friends , developed innovative microwave cooking ideas for inmates , and wrote . Martha Stewart kept in touch with supporters through her web site and was touched by the many letters . Martha Stewart played scrabble with Martha Stewart daughter Alexis during visits .

summary: On Thanksgiving Day Stewart was able to enjoy a visit from Stewart family , a privilege normally limited to weekends . By Christmas Stewart was calling for sentencing reform particularly for drug and first - time offenders . By mid - January Stewart had tried Stewart hand at ceramics and crocheting . As Stewart completed Stewart term in March Stewart was 20 pounds lighter , having taught yoga and foraged for greens on prison grounds as well as abhorring the food . After leaving Alderson at 12:30 a.m. on March 3 , 2005 , Stewart declared the 5 - month experience as & quot;life altering and life affirming.&quot ; Stewart spent Halloween , Thanksgiving , Christmas and New Year 's in prison . Stewart job there was cleaning . During Her job there , Stewart did ceramics , crocheted , taught yoga , decorated the chapel for a memorial service , became an expert on vending - machine snacks , and foraged the grounds for fresh greens for the prison salads . Stewart was grateful for the support of Stewart friends , family , colleagues , and fans . Stewart became a prison reform advocate through Stewart experience . Stewart emerged from the Alderson prison on March 4 with head held high , 20 pounds lighter and a lot wealthier , since shares in Stewart company nearly tripled in value . In a Christmas message posted on Stewart personal web site , Stewart called for sentencing reform . Stewart suggested pushing for reforms in federal sentencing guidelines for nonviolent first - time offenders and particularly for drug offenders , who would be better served in rehabilitation than prison . Stewart is scheduled to be released in early March 2004 and then must spend five months under house arrest . her company announced that Stewart would host a daytime talk show after Stewart sentence . Since Stewart conviction , her company share price has nearly tripled increasing Stewart personal stake . At Alderson Stewart had time to think , became a more sympathetic character , and got wealthier as her company 's share price tripled . her family visited at Thanksgiving . Stewart prison job was cleaning , sweeping , vacuuming and raking leaves . Via Stewart website Stewart received 15,000 fan e - mails , and said Stewart was safe , fit and healthy but found the loss of freedom and privacy difficult . Fellow inmates shielded Stewart from paparazzi . Stewart picked wild greens to augment the bad food , lost 20 pounds , learned to crochet , taught yoga , tried ceramics , decorated the chapel , ordered seeds for Stewart garden at home , and made to - do lists .

summary: Relief for the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami victims continues . More than $ 10 billion has been pledged by 42 countries and individuals . Debt relief and loans are also being offered . Concerts , telethons , and charity auctions are among the methods being used to solicit donations . President Bush made a personal contribution of $ 10,000 . President Bush recruited Former Presidents Clinton and Bush , President Bush father , to lead fundraising efforts in the U.S. President Bush signed a law permitting U.S. taxpayers to deduct contributions to tsunami relief in January 2005 from U.S. taxpayers 2004 returns . The Canadian government will match all private donations to approved aid agencies . Financial contributions for Asian Tsunami relief had exceeded $ 10 billion by Jan. 12 , 2005 . Governmental contributions passed $ 8 billion while private gifts exceeded $ 2 billion . The United Nations announced that The United Nations has secured aid commitments worth $ 717 million . Governmental contributions were led by Japan with $ 74 m. and Germany at $ 68 m. The outstanding organizational contributor was World Vision Australia which had raised $ 15.3 m through a telethon . Individual contributors were led by a Canadian couple Kroum and Eva Pindoff who gave $ 4.1 m through the Canadian Red Cross which will be matched by The Canadian government to total $ 8.2 m. Governments have pledged over eight billion dollars in aid for countries hit by the Asian tsunami and private contributions have added over two billion dollars . Countries pledging aid include : Japan , Britain , Germany , Norway , European Commission , the U.S. , Canada , Sweden , Denmark , Russia , China , Australia and Finland . Money raised from ticket sales for a Canadian TV broadcast will go to tsunami relief . An Australian telethon and Melbourne cricket match raised money for relief . Two Chinese banks have made large contributions . Individuals making large contributions include actress Sandra Bullock , President Bush , a Chinese couple and Kroum and Eva Pindoff . As of 12 January , donations and pledges continued to pour in for tsunami relief . Government donations from 42 countries exceeded $ 8 billion . Australia had raised more per capita than any other country , including donations made through a telethon and a pop concert telecast simultaneously on all three TV networks . The United Nations had aid commitments for $ 717 million for emergency relief , with Japan as the major contributor at $ 250 million . Private donations reached more than $ 2 billion , the largest from a Canadian couple , who gave $ 4.1 million , which The Canadian government will match .

Countries have pledged more than 10 billion.
Concerts are one of the methods used to solicit donations.
Charity auctions are one of the methods used to solicit donations.
The Canadian government will match donations to approved agencies.
By January, that number had exceeded 10 billion.

The United Nations announced that commitments to aid had been secured.
World Vision Australia made a contribution.
World Vision Australia has raised 15.3 million.
Sweden and Norway are among countries pledging aid.
Britain, European Commission, U.S. and Canada
The money raised from ticket sales will go.
The money raised from ticket sales will go towards tsunami relief.
The Australian telethon raised money for relief.
Contributions by individuals include Sandra Bullock

As of January, pledges continued to pour in.

summary: Countries and individuals continue to donate money and other resources to the Indian Ocean tsunami victims . The tsunami killed more than 163,000 people in 11 countries with thousands still missing . Former President Clinton was named the U.N. special envoy for tsunami relief . The Asian Development Bank pledged $ 800 million additional funds for Indonesia for medium - term economic needs beyond tsunami relief . Saudi Arabia offered the use of five aircraft for relief operations . To reach isolated regions , Switzerland loaned the U.N. three army helicopters which transported refugees and emergency workers as well as tons of humanitarian aid resources . Tsunami relief efforts continue . China 's Shanxi Province provided medical equipment and cash worth $ 180,000 . Saudi Arabia offered the use of five aircraft and a pledge of $ 100 million . Switzerland lent three army helicopters which transported refugees and emergency workers as well as tons of humanitarian aid resources for use . The government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region granted $ 192,000 while the the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Disaster Relief Fund Advisory Committee approved grants from five relief agencies for $ 2.88 million . Australian tennis ace Lleyton Hewitt raised $ 31,500 auctioning off tennis rackets while the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region superstar Andy Lou did likewise with stage costume for $ 38,000 . Countries , organizations and individuals continue to donate money , supplies and equipment to the area devastated by The tsunami . The Tiger Woods foundation is giving $ 100,000 . Memorabilia donated by professional athletes and celebrities has been auctioned for relief funds . China 's Shanxi Province sent medical equipment worth $ 180,000 to Thailand for tsunami relief . The Asian Development Bank pledged $ 800 M for Indonesia . Saudi Arabia is offering five aircraft and $ 100 M in aid . The government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region granted $ 192,000 for relief work in India , Sri Lanka and Indonesia . Former presidents Bush and Former President Clinton led private US fundraising efforts . Tsunami relief contributions continued to grow . the U.N. made Former President Clinton special ambassador for tsunami relief . China 's Shanxi Province gave Thailand $ 180,000 in medical equipment and cash . The Asian Development Bank pledged an additional $ 800 million to Indonesia . the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region donated $ 192,000 . Saudi Arabia sent five aircraft and $ 100 million . Switzerland loaned three army helicopters which transported refugees and emergency workers as well as tons of humanitarian aid resources to the U.N. . The Tiger Woods foundation gave $ 100,00 , matched by the PGA . Australian tennis player Lleyton Hewitt gave $ 45,000 from auctions of three of Australian tennis player Lleyton Hewitt rackets . the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region stars auctioned off clothes and personal items , with the proceeds going to tsunami relief .
