summary: Police arrested Dennis Rader on Feb. 25 , 2005 and identified Dennis Rader as the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 . the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 had taunted police with letters to police and the media , but efforts to find the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 failed and in 1979 letters to them and the media ceased . letters to them and the media resumed in March 2004 and the investigation of the the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 case reopened . Forensic experts studied DNA swabs that Kansas Governor Sibelius says linked Dennis Rader to Dennis Rader victims . Little else has been revealed as to how Dennis Rader was identified and tracked down . After two false arrests , Dennis Rader , was arrested Feb. 25 , 2005 . Dennis Rader was held for 10 first - degree murders , from 1974 to 1991 , but wo n't get Kansas death penalty instituted in 1994 . Local and county police , the Kansas Bureau of Investigation , and the FBI worked 31 years on 5,000 tips and evidence provided by the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 : eight letters to police and media , a victim 's necklace the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 gave to the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 girl friend , a victim 's driver 's license , the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 recorded voice and crime scene semen , thousands of DNA swabs , the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 DNA linking to Dennis Rader , and facts matching Dennis Rader biography . Wichita police arrested Dennis Rader during a traffic stop on Feb. 25 , 2005 . Dennis Rader , sent numerous taunting messages and clues in the 1970 's before going silent in 1979 . In March 2004 , Dennis Rader mailed evidence of a previously unattributed 1986 murder to the Wichita Eagle . More letters , clues and evidence followed . Thousands of tips poured in and police received help from forensics experts . Police long believed the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 graduated from Wichita State University , as Dennis Rader had . DNA evidence helped solve the BTK case . Police learned of the last two the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 victims upon arrested . Wichita police announced the identification and arrest of the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 . the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 is Dennis Rader , a 59 - year old church leader and government inspector who police believe murdered ten people between 1974 and 1991 and taunted authorities for authorities inability to catch the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 . Police received more than 5,000 tips when the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974 - 91 resurfaced in 2004 after two decades of silence . the Kansas Bureau of Investigation conducted hundreds of DNA swabs in connection with the investigation of the BTK case . Law enforcement officials revealed nothing about the evidence Law enforcement officials have against Dennis Rader . According to Kansas Governor Sibelius DNA evidence linked Dennis Rader to crime scenes .

summary: Rader confessed to six killings on the day of Rader arrest , but police revealed little detail . There was much public speculation and some media reports of possible links between Rader and BTK including talk of a computer disc and DNA evidence , but investigators remained tight - lipped . On March 1 Rader was charged with 10 murders with bail set at $ 10 million . On April 19 Rader waived Rader right to a preliminary hearing at which the prosecution would explain how the police had tied Rader to 10 murders . waived , as the DA said , & quot;prolongs the agony of the public to know.&quot ; Rader daughter did not turn Rader 's daughter father in to police . Wichita investigators continue examining other killings , for possible linkage to BTK . Reportedly , DNA from Rader 's daughter facilitated Rader identification . A computer disk in Rader final mailing linked to Rader church . On March 31 Rader was charged with 10 murders . Bail was $ 10 million . Rader next court appearance was March 15 . Rader waived a preliminary hearing at which the prosecution would explain how the police had tied Rader to the killings . Rader would plead not guilty at arraignment May 3 , and not plead insanity or plea bargain . Rader is no longer secluded from other prisoners . Kansas expected to pay $ 405,000 for Rader defense . Evidence identifying Rader as the BTK killer was found on a computer disc . Experts linked a computer disc to a computer at his church . Rader broke Rader 25 - year silence after the Wichita Eagle published an article marking the 30th anniversary of the first BTK killings . Prosecutors can not yet present Prosecutors evidence against Rader because Rader waived a preliminary hearing at which the prosecution would explain how the police had tied Rader to the killings . Nearby law enforcement agencies are reinvestigating cold cases that bear similarities to the first BTK killings . Investigators continue to examine unsolved killings over the last 31 years to determine if any can be linked to BTK . Prosecutors can not seek the death penalty for Rader since the first BTK killings occurred before the death penalty enactment . For three decades , BTK had toyed with Wichita in letters , poems and packages . It was Rader most recent mailing to a television station that helped crack the case : a computer disc . a computer disc along with DNA evidence led to Rader . Rader waived Rader right to a preliminary hearing and is expected to plead not guilty .

summary: The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , commits selective murders , slaughters and other terrorist acts . In 2003 , The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , commandos attacked two Bogota pubs , targeting US citizens who frequented two Bogota pubs . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , kidnaps hundreds of people a year for ransom and holds dozens as exchangeables , including Colombian politicians , police officers , soldiers and currently three US citizens . Colombia 's is willing to negotiate a prisoner swap with The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , to free rebel hostages , including three US citizens . negotiate is encouraged by the UN . So far The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , has not agreed to Colombia 's terms . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , has ordered The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , troops to kill Colombia 's president . The Columbian Navy captured a member of The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , , who was believed to be involved in slaughtering five members of the same family . the UN warned US citizens in Colombia 's of a possible spike in & quot;terrorist activity.&quot ; FARC , with about 17,000 fighters and a smaller leftist guerilla group are locked in a 40 - year civil war with Colombia 's . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , allegedly finances The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , through drug trafficking and kidnappings . About 3,500 people are killed yearly . Colombia 's president is ready to negotiate a prisoner swap with The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , , allegedly finances The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , through drug trafficking and kidnappings . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , , is accused of committing murders and slaughters as well as terrorist acts in different part of Colombia 's . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , kidnaps hundreds each year for ransom and holds dozens of & quot;exchangeables&quot ; including politicians , police , soldiers , and three US contractors . Colombia 's president has appealed for international support in Colombia 's war against the rebel groups . Colombia 's president has indicated a readiness to negotiate a prisoner swap with The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , . Colombia 's president held talks with The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , and designated a safe haven until The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , hijacked an airliner and kidnapped a senator . In 2003 The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , bombed American - frequented pubs and abducted three Americans after a plane crash . In 2004 The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , killed five members of the same family and bombed a peasant home , killing one . the UN designated The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , a terrorist organization and aided Colombia 's financially in Colombia 's anti - The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , war . Colombia 's president offered to swap 50 jailed rebels for 50 hostages . The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , - government fighting kills 3,500 yearly . A The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , bomb narrowly missed Colombia 's president in 2002 . Colombia 's president is pursuing an aggressive military offensive against The FARC , Colombia 's largest leftist guerrilla force , .

summary: In November , Colombian police arrested a FARC assassin , the army killed a FARC leader , and the court approved the extradition of a FARC chief to the US to face narcotics trafficking and money laundering charges . FARC rebels murdered four indigenous Indian leaders in less than a week . The government and FARC continued to argue over details of a prisoner swap . The UN urged Colombia to speed up negotiations for hostage release . December 2 , Colombia announced Colombia would pardon 23 FARC members to facilitate reaching a humanitarian accord with FARC . Colombian police may have kidnapped a FARC rebel in Venezuela . FARC rejected a government proposal to hold talks aimed at exchanging rebels for hostages held by the guerillas . FARC asked the president to grant FARC the two southern demilitarized zones , before discussions could take place . Colombia denied asked because Colombia has to guarantee the safety of the people across Colombia . The UN urged hostage release . FARC rebels released 12 hostages . Colombia plans to pardon more than 30 members of FARC as The government and FARC negotiate a prisoner swap . FARC rejected a government proposal to hold talks aimed at exchanging rebels for hostages held by the guerillas unless the two southern demilitarized zones were demilitarized . Colombia rejected a government proposal to hold talks aimed at exchanging rebels for hostages held by the guerillas but released 50 jailed guerillas to build confidence . FARC followed with release of five kidnap victims . FARC killed another indigenous leader , Pervis Pacheco of the Kankuamo Indians and are believed to have killed the leader of Arhuaco Indians . the court approved extradition of a FARC chief , among others , to the US to face charges of narco - trafficking and money laundering . Colombia was to pardon 23 FARC members as The government and FARC negotiate prisoner exchanges . Colombia again refused asked . FARC holds 1600 hostages . Police arrested a FARC assassin . FARC killed four indigenous Indian leaders . Colombia released 50 jailed guerillas and pardoned 23 . Five FARC rebels died in a clash with the army . Colombia approved extradition of a FARC chief to the US . A FARC leader was seized in Venezuela and moved to Colombia .

summary: On June 16 , 2005 Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham insisted there was nothing wrong with Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham living on a yacht owned by the executive of MZM , Inc. for which Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham had helped gain government contracts or selling a San Diego home for $ 1,675,000 to the executive who resold a San Diego home for $ 975,000 . On July 1 federal agents raided a San Diego home and the MZM , Inc. offices and yacht in Washington . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham soon announced that Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham would not seek reelection and the executive who resold it for $ 975,000 stepped down . On August 13 Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham asked donors for permission to use donors campaign contributions for legal expenses . By July 2005 Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham was under investigation by the FBI , U.S. Attorney 's Office , Defense Criminal Investigative Service , the IRS and a federal grand jury probe . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham received MZM , Inc. PAC money and personal donations from MZM , Inc. President , Mitchell Wade . MZM President , Mitchell Wade paid a supposedly inflated price for Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham and Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham paid MZM President , Mitchell Wade questionably little money to live on MZM President , Mitchell Wade yacht in DC . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham promoted MZM , Inc. defense contracts , contributed to and served on a Wade - run charity board , and spoke at an MZM , Inc. company party . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham requested donors ' permission to transfer campaign funds to Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham legal defense fund . the FBI and other federal agencies are investigating Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham for selling a San Diego home in November 2003 to MZM President , Mitchell Wade for an inflated price . Agencies are probing MZM President , Mitchell Wade efforts to repay Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham for Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham support in gaining federal contracts . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham was living on a yacht owned by the executive of MZM , Inc. for which he had helped gain government contracts . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham defended Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham boat arrangement as proper saying that Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham paid fees and services in lieu of rent . Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham is asking Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham contributors , including MZM President , Mitchell Wade , for permission to use his contributors , including Wade , campaign donations for Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham legal defense . Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham , R - California , is a favorite of defense contractors who contribute heavily to Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham political campaign . The CEO of one company , MZM , Mitchell Wade , contributes to Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham campaign and PAC , but supports Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham in other ways . When in Washington , Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham lives aboard MZM President , Mitchell Wade yacht docked at a Potomac River yacht club and pays only docking fees . MZM President , Mitchell Wade purchased Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham home in San Diego for over $ 1.6 M and a few months later sold Cunningham 's home in San Diego for a $ 700,000 loss suggesting that Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham was paid an inflated price . After sold , Rep. Randall & quot;Duke&quot ; Cunningham bought another home for over $ 2.5M.

summary: Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28 , 2005 after pleading guilty to taking at least $ 2.4 million in bribes to help four unnamed co - conspirators win defense contracts . The FBI continued The FBI investigation of defense contractors . On Feb. 18 prosecutors recommended that Cunningham serve the maximum ten years in prison , pay $ 1.5 million in taxes and forfeit $ 1.85 million in bribe money and items provided by co - conspirators . On March 5 Cunningham was sentenced to 8 years and 4 months in prison and ordered to pay $ 1.8 million in restitution . On November 28 , 2005 Cunningham pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit at least $ 2.4 million in bribes , the most ever congressional bribes , and $ 1 million tax evasion . Wade was indicted . four unnamed co - conspirators were Brent Wilkes , ADCS , Inc. ; Thomas Kontogiannis ; and John T. Kongogiannis . Prosecutors could have asked for 20 years incarceration , but requested 10 years , payment of $ 1.5 million in taxes and penalties , and forfeiture of $ 1.85 million in bribes . Wade pled guilty February 24 , awaiting sentencing . On March 3 , Cunningham was sentenced to eight years and four months , the longest for any congressman , and $ 1.8 Million restitution . Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking at least $ 2.4 million in bribes to help friends and contributors win federal defense contracts . The FBI is still conducting The FBI investigation of defense contractors and others tied to Cunningham . Cunningham kept a & quot;bribe menu&quot ; on congressional stationary indicating how much Cunningham demanded in exchange for federal contracts . A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison . Cunningham was also ordered to pay $ 1.8 million in restitution . Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking $ 2.4 M in bribes from defense contractors . Cunningham pled guilty to one count of tax evasion and one count of conspiracy to commit bribery , tax evasion , wire and mail fraud . Cunningham had received cash , cars , rugs , antiques , furniture , yacht club fees , moving expenses and vacations for helping contractors win government contracts . A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison . The government seized Cunningham share of profits from the $ 2.6 M sale of Cunningham home . The government will auction the gift items that Cunningham illegally received .

summary: The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) and the French National Space Center have signed an agreement to initiate a satellite project which will gather atmospheric data . India will build the satellite and the French National Space Center the scientific instruments . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) is also considering scientific experiments from the US , UK , Sweden , Bulgaria and Germany for an unmanned lunar mission . India hopes to launch a manned mission within seven years . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) is assisting the Jharkhand Space Application Center launch a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities . Afghanistan is requesting to piggyback on a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities to assist Afghanistan citizens . The space agencies of India and the French National Space Center have signed an agreement to cooperate in launching the satellite . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) has short - listed experiments from the US , UK , Sweden . Bulgaria and Germany for a slot on The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) unmanned moon mission , Chandrayaan-1 . the French National Space Center and NASA will have x - ray and laser equipment on the satellite . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) will provide satellite connectivity to the Jharkhand Space Application Center for a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities . a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities will also function in Afghanistan . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) and the French National Space Center will cooperate on a satellite to track tropical atmospheric conditions . The Indian Space Research Organization ( ISRO ) has short - listed experiments from five nations ( US , UK , Sweden , Bulgaria , Germany ) for a slot on the satellite . India can send a man into space within seven years . India first astronaut flew on the Soviet Salyut 7 in 1984 . Another died in the Columbia shuttle disaster . India plans a telemedicine system to connect hospitals and patients via satellite . India plans flight - testing of India cryogenic rocket . India sought black - market electrical components for rockets . India space program is developing on several fronts . India is planning an unmanned lunar mission . Experiments from five countries ( the U.S. and four European nations ) are short - listed for an unmanned lunar mission . India has an agreement with the French National Space Center to launch a satelite perhaps in 2008 to make climate predictions more accurate . India will set up a telemedicine system , linking doctors at the best hospitals with patients across India . Afghanistan has asked India for help setting up a similar program in Afghanistan using Indian satellites .

summary: India successfully launched two satellites from one rocket for the first time . To decrease costs and increase launches , India developed a universal launch pad for all future vehicles . India will host two international space conferences ( planetary exploration and space law ) . India has signed an agreement with the European Space Agency and is talking with NASA regarding NASA participation in India unmanned lunar launch . India launch of the INSAT-4A has been delayed by the European Space Agency . Boeing cancelled Boeing agreement with India to jointly produce communication satellites . India and Russia are collaborating on the development of a youth communication satellite . For the first time , India is set to launch two satellites in a single mission . One is for mapping and the other for communications . India will host two international space conferences ( planetary exploration and space law ) . Some 225 delegates including many from the US , China , Japan , Canada , France , Malaysia , Sri Lanka and Indonesia will attend . The ISRO announced the payloads from the US , Bulgaria , Germany and Britain for the Chandrayaan-1 mission . Launch of the INSAT-4A from French Guyana has been delayed . India and Russia are working on a satellite for communication between youths of India and Russia . India space program began in 1972 . India aspires to be a major space power . India developed a unique universal launching pad and plans a sophisticated propellant plant for India launch vehicle , delayed by sanctions following India 1998 nuclear testing . India has launched eleven remote - sensing satellites and two satellites in one mission . Communication satellites include Hamsat for Ham radio and distance - learning Edusat . India and Russia plan a youth communication satellite . In 2005 India hosted international conferences on planetary exploration and space law . Europe 's Ariane program problems delayed launch of India telecast and communication satellite INSAT-4A. Boeing withdrew from Indian satellite cooperation . The Indian Prime Minister has criticized economic sanctions imposed after India 's 1998 nuclear testing , but noted that economic sanctions imposed after the 1998 nuclear weapons tests have not hindered India scientific progress . India launched one rocket carrying two satellites , one for more detailed mapping , the other for home radio operators . India first unmanned moon mission , scheduled for 2007 - 2008 , will carry three European payloads and perhaps one U.S. payload . Meanwhile India is working with Russia to develop a satellite to enable youths in India and Russia to communicate . India will host twin international conferences on planetary exploration and space law for about 225 delegates in June .

summary: In October , 2004 , the Dover , PA School Board ordered that biology students be told evolution & quot;is a theory , not a fact&quot ; and & quot;intelligent design is an explanation of the origin of life that differs&quot ; from evolution , and encouraged to read & quot;Of Pandas & amp ; People&quot ; , added to the school library . Trial began September , 26 , 2005 . Plaintiffs argued intelligent design is not scientific , but religious ; that board members had religious motivation ; and that intelligent design and & quot;Pandas&quot ; are recast creationism which has been banned from public school science classes by the Supreme Court as a violation of the first amendment 's establishment clause . the Dover , PA School Board passed a resolution in October , 2004 requiring 9th grade biology students be told that evolution is a theory , not a fact , and that intelligent design is an alternative explanation of the origin of life . the Dover , PA School Board is being sued by 11 parents of students who charge the Dover , PA School Board is trying to promote a religion in violation of the US Constitution . the Dover , PA School Board argues the Dover , PA School Board is informing students about differences of opinion , not endorsing any religious view . Trial is underway . PA Dover School Board voted requiring teachers to read a brief statement about intelligent design to students before teaching classes on evolution . Intelligent design implies that nature is so complex nature must be the work of a single creator rather than evolution . the Dover , PA School Board stated that intelligent design provides an alternative to teaching evolution and denies that intelligent design is & quot;religion in disguise.&quot ; Dover , PA parents brought suit against the Dover , PA School Board charging that teaching & quot;intelligent design&quot ; is a clear violation of the principle of separation of church and state . the Dover , PA School Board passed a resolution requiring students in a 9th grade biology course be told evolution & quot;is a theory , not a fact&quot ; and & quot;intelligent design is an explanation of the origin of life that differs&quot ; from evolution . board members made it clear board members believed the origin of life was guided by a heavenly hand . Eleven Dover , PA families are suing the Dover , PA School Board alleging the measure violates the constitutional separation of church and state . The American Civil Liberties Union and Americans United for Separation of Church and State are assisting Dover parents .

summary: Defendants argued intelligent design is science , not religion , because intelligent design testable & quot;irreducible complexity&quot ; claim implies an intelligent designer but not necessarily God . One board member lied to hide that a church bought the & quot;Pandas&quot ; books . On December 20 , 2005 the judge ruled that the board 's action violates the constitution . & quot;Intelligent design is & quot;a religious view , a mere re - labeling of creationism&quot ; . the judge excoriated board members for lying in board members testimony , for not bothering to understand intelligent design and for the & quot;breathtaking inanity of the board 's decision&quot ; . ruled is binding only in one Pennsylvania district . Dover will pay large legal fees . For three weeks plaintiffs in the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School District trial presented expert witnesses who testified that intelligent design does not meet the definition of science because intelligent design can not be proved or disproved . For the next three weeks , the defense called witnesses who testified that intelligent design is not based on religious beliefs , but on observable , physical evidence from nature . the judge ruled that compelling teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution . Dover residents ousted all eight school board members running for re - election who put Dover in the global spotlight . At the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School District trial , a biochemistry professor at Lehigh and lawyers at the Thomas More Law Center testified for teaching intelligent design as a credible scientific theory . Scientists testifying for the parents dismissed intelligent design because intelligent design ca n't be tested by experiment . the judge ruled that teaching intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution . the judge wrote that the overwhelming evidence established that intelligent design is a religious view and not a scientific theory and intelligent design inclusion in public schools violates the separation of church and state . Both sides agreed to a bench trial without a jury , common in First Amendment cases where arguments are about legal rather than factual issues . At the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School District trial , board members said board members wanted to & quot;encourage critical thinking.&quot ; However , the parents presented evidence the board 's purpose was religious and the intelligent design statement was a compromise after board members could not teach creationism . the judge ruled that compelling biology teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution . Four days after final arguments in the case , Dover residents ousted board members .

summary: Steroid use appears rampant in Major League Baseball based on former player revelations and the BALCO steroid distribution scandal . Steroids were banned by Major League Baseball in 2004 but banned did not include designer or precursor steroids . The new Anabolic Steroid Control Act makes steroid precursors controlled substances . Congressional hearings on steroid use are being held . Former and current team members and League officials are being called to testify , some by subpoena . Major League Baseball testing program is weak compared to World Anti - Doping Agency standards . Lawmakers are considering stronger action if Major League Baseball does not impose mandatory bans to police Major League Baseball . Major League Baseball players who have admitted to using steroids include Ken Caminiti , Mark McGwire and Jose Conseco . Players suspected of steroid use include Barry Bonds , Sammy Sosa , Jason Giambi , Rafael Palmeiro , Ivan Rodriguez and Juan Gonzalez . Major League Baseball recently toughened penalties of fines from $ 10,000 to $ 100,000 and suspensions from 10 days to one year are far below international anti - doping standards . US lawmakers passed The new Anabolic Steroid Control Act . In US lawmakers investigation of steroid use in Major League Baseball , US lawmakers found the penalties for positive steroid tests inadequate . After the death of Ken Caminiti , the US House of Representatives amended The new Anabolic Steroid Control Act to include additional types of steroids . Major League Baseball players who are accused of , or admitted , using steroids are Mark McGwire , Jose Conseco , Sammy Sosa , Jason Giambi and Raphael Palmiero . Commissioner Bud Selig said that The League 's testing program showed a drop in positive tests for steroids . The League 's testing program has been criticized as too lenient . Baseball executives and players union leaders have agreed to toughen penalties for the current season . Major League Baseball players Ken Caminiti , Mark McGwire , and Jose Conseco admitted taking steroids . Barry Bonds , Sammy Sosa , Jason Giambi , Rafael Palmeiro , Ivan Rodriguez , and Juan Gonzalez are accused or suspected of steroid use . Caminiti claimed half the players used steroid . 5 - 7 percent of players tested positive in 2003 and 1 - 2 percent in 2005 . Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig investigated steroid use in 1998 and urged banning over - the - counter sales . A pamphlet in English and Spanish on steroids ' effects was distributed to players . Drug tests for players began in 2004 . Some steroids became controlled substances . Congress held hearings on baseball steroid use .

summary: Congressional hearings and an undercover probe investigating illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball and other sports continues . Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig admitted Major League Baseball policy is not strong enough and has proposed much stricter penalties . much stricter penalties include a 50 - game suspension for the first offense and a lifetime ban for the third one . much stricter penalties would apply to minor - league players next year . Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig also requested amphetamines be added to the banned substances . Congress has threatened to implement a testing system unless Major League Baseball strengthened the League 's policy . The Players Association has not responded to much stricter penalties . Under pressure from Congress , The Players Association toughened drug testing rules and penalties again for the 2006 season . Suspensions will be increased to 50 games for a first offense , 100 for a second , and a lifetime ban for the third . Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball . News of an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball surprised Major League Baseball officials . Rafael Palmeiro was suspended 10 days for a positive steroid test . Rafael Palmeiro denied intentionally taking the drug . Other players with 10 - day steroid test suspensions were Felix Heredia and Carlos Almanzar . New doping allegations surfaced about Barry Bonds . Congress has launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball . To highlight illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball , baseball heavy hitters Mark McGuire , Raphael Palmeiro and Sammy Sosa testified before the responsible congressional committee . In a letter to The Players Association , Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig proposes a 50 - game suspension for first offenders instead of the current 10 - game suspension . A second offense would result in a 100 - day suspension and a third , a lifetime ban . The Players Association has concerns since several steroid agents stay in the blood stream for a long period . A one - time user who swore off could show positive in future testing . Congressional investigators chided Major League Baseball leaders for being uncooperative regarding steroid use and urged star players to take public responsibility for star players actions . Congress also launched an undercover probe . Players proposed strengthening the collective bargaining steroid proposal . Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig proposed a 50 - game suspension for first offenders , 100 - game suspension for second , and lifetime ban for third . 2003 tests showed 104 steroid users . Eleven players were suspended for steroids in 2005 . Felix Heredia , Carlos Almanzar and Rafael Palmeiro tested positive . BALCO 's Victor Conte and James Valente , Bonds trainer Greg Anderson , and chemist Patrick Arnold were charged or sentenced concerning steroid distribution .

summary: Bamboo shoots must be properly prepared to avoid consuming naturally produced hydrogen cyanide . Bamboo can help makeshift buildings better withstand earthquakes . Innovative bamboo products include : hardwood flooring , paneling , cabinets , countertops , utensils , plates , bowls , cutting boards , shower curtains , and products based on fiber , fiber pulps or veneers . Bamboo 's has greater tensile strength than steel . Bamboo 's can be harvested every 3 to 5 years , but entire bamboo stands die - off every 60 years , threatening crop collapse and endangering China 's endangered Giant Pandas , who are dependent on arrow bamboo . Bamboo has many uses . In the home , Bamboo is used for flooring , kitchen cabinets , counter tops , and chairs . India is allowing India islands that were struck by the tsunami , to build makeshift houses from bamboo and other woods , which can withstand quakes . Ethiopia hopes to optimize ways of producing bamboo to reduce poverty . Large areas of arrow bamboo provide food for giant pandas in northwest China . Now giant pandas are suffering from hunger because large tracts of arrow bamboo died . It takes 10 - 15 years for new plants to grow . Bamboo is increasing used for household items and furniture . Bamboo main use remains as a sturdy alternative for hardwood flooring . Bamboo has greater tensile strength than steel and costs less and lasts longer than oak flooring . Bamboo is environmentally friendly and sustainable since Bamboo grows fast and can be harvested within five years . Bamboo shoots are a traditional part of Asian cuisine but must be properly prepared to avoid causing harm . The bamboo plant is the staple panda food . But when The bamboo plant flowers and produces seeds , pandas will not eat The bamboo plant and are in danger of starving . Bamboo is used for flooring , paneling , and furnishings . Bamboo tensile strength is greater than steel , Bamboo 's harvestable in 3 - 5 years , and Bamboo 's inexpensive . India makes bamboo housing for earthquake survivors . Ethiopia is developing Ethiopia extensive bamboo commercially with China 's help . A pulp mill for bamboo - like Arundo donax would benefit Alabama economically but residents fear bamboo - like Arundo donax invasiveness . California imported bamboo - like Arundo donax for windbreaks . Giant pandas are increasing in China 's due to expanded bamboo forests and moving pandas when local bamboo flowers and becomes inedible . KFC in China 's substitutes bamboo shoots for coleslaw . Incorrect preparation of fresh shoots risks hydrogen cyanide exposure .

summary: China 's National Special Program for Food Security assists Nigeria eliminate poverty through Bamboo - based development , using Nigeria existing under utilized bamboo forests to turn out about 300 byproducts . Over 20 insects plague northwest China 's arrow bamboo , a major food source for giant Pandas . The U.S. National Zoo 's research advances in giant panda reproductive cycles and artificial insemination will increase endangered giant panda populations in captivity and in the wild . India is building two commercially viable , environmentally friendly , one - megawatt , & quot;green power&quot ; bamboo gasification - based electricity plants . A wide variety of bamboo fiber rugs are available , including kiln - dried and carbonized bamboo with polyurethane coatings . Nigeria is using bamboo to revitalize Nigeria agriculture . Nigeria has set up a database exploring Nigeria abundant bamboo resource to produce byproducts . A state in northeast India plans to set up power stations that run on bamboo to help meet the regions energy needs . A Chinese company has successfully produced fiber from maize and blended fiber from maize with bamboo fiber to make environment - friendly clothes . Forestry experts in northwest China 's have identified Over 20 insects . Help for pandas is being arranged . China 's earned as much as $ 3.5B in foreign exchange from the bamboo - based sector in 2003 . Nigeria hopes to follow that example and effectively explore Nigeria 's existing under utilized bamboo forests . India , is set to pioneer environmentally friendly power stations that run on bamboo . New products from bamboo include non - slip rugs , fiber for clothing and pre - fabricated quake - shelters . Bamboo 's 60 - year blooming and seeding cycle and the identification of Over 20 insects threaten the staple of giant Pandas diet . Retailers offer bamboo - extract towels and bamboo rugs . A Chinese company introduced bamboo fiber in 2004 . A bamboo - maize blend makes soft , comfortable , wrinkle - resistant clothing . Bamboo earned China 's $ 3.5 billion in 2003 . Nigeria is partnering with China 's to develop Nigeria vast bamboo reserve . India is pioneering a power station to turn bamboo into gas then electricity and run local paper mills . Arrow bamboo , plagued by over 20 insects , is low in nutrition but giant Pandas main food . Logging and development threaten bamboo forests . Starving people in Malawi resorted to eating bamboo seeds . Bamboo shoots contaminated with botulism sickened 163 in Thailand .

summary: Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , first came to national attention with Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , electrifying keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention in July 2004 . Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , went on to win overwhelmingly in the race for U.S. Senator . Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , was outstanding for Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , inclusive rhetoric , ability to attract support of liberals and white middle - class voters , and Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , fund raising for Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , own and other Democratic candidates . While running Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , own campaign Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , stumped for other candidates in more than a dozen states . In November 2004 Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , was already being touted as a future presidential candidate . Barack Obama , a black state senator in Illinois , graduated Harvard Law School as the first black President of the Harvard Law Review . summary: During Obama first 15 months as a U.S. Senator ( Jan 2005 - Mar 2006 ) , Obama became better known and more widely admired . Obama book & quot;Dreams From My Father&quot ; became a bestseller . On the senate floor Obama demonstrated willingness to work on a bipartisan basis on foreign and domestic issues . In party affairs Obama continued Obama successes as a fundraiser . One political analyst said , & quot;The party needs Obama and for all One political analyst know , the nation needs him.&quot ; Some compared Obama to John F. Kennedy but Doris Kearns Goodwin warned there were also similarities to William J. Bryan . Obama is the 5th black Senator in U.S. history . In 2005 Obama received Harvard Law School 's highest award , at which Obama criticized the Katrina debacle . Obama published a Time magazine article about President Lincoln . Obama criticized the Bush administration and called for troop withdrawal from Iraq . In 2006 Obama met with the Foreign Minister in Israel . Obama and senior Senator McCain worked on ethics reform , had a public spat , and made nice . As Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee Vice Chairman , Obama helped raise $ 6.5 million . Obama won a Grammy for His book & quot;Dreams From My Father&quot ; . Obama was received like a rock star and hero at a luncheon where Obama was bestowed the Harvard Law School Association Award . Obama took a 10 - day tour of the Middle East that included visits to Iraq , Kuwait , Jordan , Palestinian territories , and Israel . Obama met with the Foreign Minister in Israel and conveyed to the Foreign Minister in Israel the nation support for Israel as Israel leader Ariel Sharon lay stricken by a stroke . Obama won a Grammy Award for Obama readings of His book & quot;Dreams From My Father&quot ; . At a sold - out luncheon for black alumni at Harvard Law School 's , Obama was introduced as a rock star and hero . Obama urged the nearly 1,000 attendees to take personal responsibility in combating urban poverty . In 2005 Obama called for troop reduction in Iraq and a timeframe for phased withdrawal . Obama visited Israel and met with the Foreign Minister in Israel and mended a rift with senior Senator McCain over lobbying reform . Obama won the Best Spoken Word Grammy for Obama autobiographical & quot;Dreams From My Father&quot ; . Obama became an important fundraiser for fellow democrats and tweaked the press for the press fawning coverage of Obama .

summary: Cell - phone driving laws are having limited success in passage . Federal bills died in committee . Without a national consensus , existing state and local government laws vary widely . Drivers either ignore or are unaware of existing laws . Enforcement is not uniform . Lobbyists oppose legislation and argue driver distraction by various factors is at fault not cell - phone technology . A survey of cell phone records and accidents in Australia conducted by the U.S. based Insurance Institute for Highway Safety concludes that there is little difference between hand - held and hands - free device driver distraction . A survey of cell phone records and accidents in Australia conducted by the U.S. based Insurance Institute for Highway Safety confirms that cell - phone use while driving increases injuries and deaths . The District of Columbia , New York and New Jersey passed legislation that bans using hand - held cell phones while driving . More than 400,000 tickets and warnings have been issued since New York first enacted legislation that bans using hand - held cell phones while driving . New Mexico and Chicago City only allow hands - free cell phone . Texas is considering cell phone laws . An Insurance Institute of Highway Safety survey said using any cell phones while driving is dangerous . Drivers using cell phones are four times as likely to end up in a crash as drivers who did n't use a cell phone . Forty - five countries banned hand - held phone use while driving . In the US only New York , New Jersey and The District of Columbia completely ban hand - held phone use . Some states direct hand - held bans to specific groups such as school bus drivers or those on learner 's permits . Some municipalities have enacted bans but some have been overturned by states declining to take action against cell phone use . Some jurisdictions permit hands - free cell phone use . Cell phone bills in Texas and California failed to carry . Laws are often ignored and enforcement spotty . However , Washington police average 600 tickets and 250 warnings each month . The District of Columbia , NY state , New Jersey , Connecticut and Chicago City ban the use of hand - held cell phones while driving . Some states or cities ban use with learner 's permits , by school bus drivers , by minors for six months after getting minors licenses , or require hands - free phones . Every state has considered restrictions but bills seldom pass . Some states , including Florida , prohibit local governments from restricting cell phone use . Hands - free and hand - held cell phones are equally distracting . Laws are often ignored . Enforcement is spotty . Hand - held phone use while driving is banned in 45 countries , including Australia , Germany , France , Britain and Japan .

summary: The State Legislature group concluded that States are focusing cell - phone legislation on younger drivers and school bus drivers . cell - phone legislation are more likely to pass and maintain cell - phone legislation constituents support . The cell - phone industry states that the percentage of accidents caused are very low . Judging cell - phone law results are difficult due to the lack of clear evidence in accidents except from witnesses or driver admissions . Driver education is a large part of cell - phone law enforcement . A National Highway Traffic Safety Administration survey prompted the Department of Defense to restrict driver cell - phone use on military facilities . Enforcement policies vary by military base . In 2005 , 38 states tried to pass legislation restricting cell phones while driving . Bills were passed or are still being considered in 22 states . The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to restrict young drivers because teens account for a large share of traffic fatalities and cell phone use increases account . However , enforcing laws for young drivers is difficult . Both the U.S. Virgin Islands and Lackland Air Force Base have cell phone laws in place . Every state has considered legislation on cell phones behind the wheel but only a few have banned cell phones behind the wheel unless cell phones behind the wheel are hands - free . Connecticut and Chicago have joined New York , New Jersey and DC in prohibiting use of hand - held phones . Many states have put limits on teens using cell phones while teens drive . Enforcement of laws banning cell phone use while driving is a problem . Nearly everyone supports laws banning cell phone use while driving , nearly everyone ignores laws banning cell phone use while driving . the Department of Defense approved restrictions on cell phone use by motorists but left it for the military services and individual bases to decide how to enforce restrictions on cell phone use by motorists . the U.S. Virgin Islands now bans hand - held cell phone use while driving . Eleven states including Colorado , Delaware , Maryland and Tennessee ban cell phone use by young drivers . California prohibits phone use while driving by bus drivers but not others . Under a Pentagon directive , bans on cell phone use while driving are becoming common on military bases . In 2005 , 38 states tried to pass restrictive legislation . Effectiveness is difficult to assess because drivers or witnesses must confirm cell phone use coincided with accidents . Enforcement is difficult because officers ca n't easily ascertain drivers ' ages or if drivers ' are using hands - free phones .

summary: In August 2003 , former Liberian President , Charles Taylor , accepted asylum in Nigeria from 17 counts of war crimes in Sierra Leone . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor has been accused of violating the asylum agreement by harboring Al - Qaeda terrorists , interfering with Liberian presidential elections and an assassination attempt on the Guinea President . The U.N.-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone is pressuring Nigeria to send former Liberian President , Charles Taylor home to Liberia . U.N. peacekeepers would transfer former Liberian President , Charles Taylor to Sierra Leone for prosecution . Reversing an earlier statement , Liberia new President states that former Liberian President , Charles Taylor should go directly to Sierra Leone from Nigeria since former Liberian President , Charles Taylor has not been indicted in Liberia . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor fled Liberia in August 2003 accepting an invitation from Nigeria for exile . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor lived in a luxury villa near the town of Calibar near the border with Cameroon . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor was accused of continuing to meddle in Liberian politics , of funding and planning an assassination attempt on the Guinea President and of backing Sierra Leone rebels . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor was also said to give support to Al - Qaeda in Al - Qaeda efforts to destabilize West Africa . In March 2006 , Nigeria offered to return former Liberian President , Charles Taylor to Liberia for trial , but Liberia did n't want former Liberian President , Charles Taylor so former Liberian President , Charles Taylor remained in a luxury villa near the town of Calibar near the border with Cameroon . After former Liberian President , Charles Taylor fled Liberia , former Liberian President , Charles Taylor took comfortable asylum in Nigeria , agreeing not to interfere in Liberia or other countries . Nigeria would return former Liberian President , Charles Taylor to Liberia , only if a newly elected Liberia government formally requested return , but not directly to The U.N.-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone . From Nigeria , former Liberian President , Charles Taylor meddled in Liberia elections and implicated Al - Qaida and blood diamonds in an assassination attempt on the Guinea President , so former Liberian President , Charles Taylor could move to Guinea . In March 2006 Liberia 's new President requested former Liberian President , Charles Taylor be released to Sierra Leone . President Bush and Obasanjo were to discuss former Liberian President , Charles Taylor on March 29 . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor fled to Nigeria in August 2003 and is under house arrest at a riverside villa in the town of Calibar . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor regularly defies restrictions against travel , political activity or media contact . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor is actively trying to destabilize West Africa , spending money former Liberian President , Charles Taylor looted from Liberia . former Liberian President , Charles Taylor meddles in Liberian affairs , harbors members of Al - Qaeda , and ordered an assassination attempt against Guinea President Conte . Obasanjo agreed to turn former Liberian President , Charles Taylor over to Liberia but is pressured to send former Liberian President , Charles Taylor to war crimes court in Sierra Leone where former Liberian President , Charles Taylor is under indictment for crimes against humanity while backing rebels .

summary: Charles Taylor disappeared 48 hours after the Nigerian government rescinded Charles Taylor political asylum . Bowing to international pressure the Nigerian government was preparing to take Charles Taylor into custody to extradite Charles Taylor to Sierra Leone . United Nations chief Kofi Annan requested West African countries to deny Charles Taylor refuge and arrest Charles Taylor . Charles Taylor was arrested the next day by Nigerian police while attempting to cross the border into Cameroon . Upon Charles Taylor involuntary return to the Nigerian government Charles Taylor was flown by the United Nations peacekeeping force to Sierra Leone and was read the arrest warrant . Charles Taylor will appear before the Special Court on April 3 . On the night of March 27 , 2006 Charles Taylor vanished . Charles Taylor spiritual advisor said Charles Taylor was hiding somewhere in West Africa . On March 29 Charles Taylor was arrested while attempting to cross over into Cameroon . Charles Taylor was detained under armed guard and then placed on a presidential jet bound for the Nigerian government . Charles Taylor left Monrovia , the Nigerian government an hour after arrival on a United Nations helicopter to Freetown , Sierra Leone where Charles Taylor was delivered to the Special Court . Charles Taylor was due to make Charles Taylor first court appearance on April 3 at 3 p.m. Charles Taylor vanished the night of March 27 , 2006 , after the Nigerian government said the Nigerian government would end his political asylum and allow Charles Taylor to face indictment by the Special Court . On March 29 Charles Taylor was arrested by the Nigerian government police trying to escape into Cameroon . Charles Taylor was detained under guard , flown to the Nigerian government , arrested by United Nations peacekeeping forces , and extradited by helicopter to Sierra Leone on March 30 . the Special Court indicted Charles Taylor on 11 counts of crimes against humanity , making Charles Taylor the first African head of state to face an international war crimes tribunal . Charles Taylor vanished two days after President Obasanjo said the Nigerian government could take Charles Taylor into custody . Nigerian police arrested Charles Taylor a day after Charles Taylor escape , as Charles Taylor tried to cross into Cameroon with sacksful of dollars and euros . Charles Taylor was detained under armed guard in a military camp before being put in handcuffs on a presidential jet Wednesday bound for the Nigerian government . An hour after arrival Charles Taylor left for Sierra Leone aboard a UN helicopter . Charles Taylor was to make his first court appearance on Monday , April 3 , 2006 , Charles Taylor .

summary: Electric power networks are vulnerable to physical attacks ( conventional explosives or nuclear electromagnetic pulse ) and computer attacks ( external or internal ) against the internet - based supervisory control and data acquisition computers and networks that remotely control power generation and transmission . Recognized cyber - security improvements need to be implemented more comprehensively , especially against documented threats from Al - Qaida , and older , less secure equipment replaced . Network stability and capacity , and ensured power locally , can be improved with on - site power generation that can also increase power available to the network , such as from fuels , solar , wind , and fuel cells . Excess power can be stored as hydrogen . Security experts warned that terrorists could unleash electromagnetic bombs that can be catastrophic . The U.S. is particularly vulnerable because The U.S. relies heavily on telecommunications and electronics . Homeland Security is being urged to set up mechanisms to stop attacks and restore power . Electric company officials have been warned that Electric company officials need to focus more on cyber - security to prevent hackers from attacking U.S. electric power grids . Many nuclear power plants in The U.S. lack sirens warning of a nuclear emergency if electricity also was blacked out . Many analysts believe the biggest threat to the power grid is from companies using older equipment that is more susceptible to attack and their reluctance to update to new computers . Former counterterrorism chief Richard Clarke opined that a sophisticated hacker could probably get into each of the three US power networks and bring down sections . Computers make The U.S. infrastructure more efficient , but Computers also make the nation 's infrastructure more vulnerable . Improved planning and additional power plants would seem to improve reliability and lessen the chance for a widespread blackout like the one in 2003 . Alternative power sources could also benefit . Electrical grid vulnerability has grown as equipment is controlled through the Internet or phone , older equipment becomes susceptible to attack , and electric companies ' cybersecurity remains inadequate . Homeland Security has n't yet assessed cyberattack threats . An electromagnetic pulse could damage electrical power systems . In 2003 , fifty million Americans lost power in a blackout originating in Ohio . New York has improved power grid monitoring and is increasing in - state generation through fuel cells , windmills , and solar panels . Texas protects Texas grid by remaining independent . Terrorist attacks are being simulated using computer models . The 2005 Energy Bill calls for increased energy production and grid modernization .

summary: Other power grid vulnerabilities include accidental line cuts during maintenance , equipment malfunction or failure , old grid infrastructure and poor grid design causing power loss over wider areas . Improvements in grid architectures will increase network resilience . Deregulation resulted in lower margins for reserve power capacity and transmission capacity , as well as loss of experienced personnel . As companies specialized more in generation or transmission , supervisory data became proprietary and unavailable to regional grid managers . An August 2005 federal law will create a process for mandating reliability rules . Energy conservation and smart appliances that cut back during power grid stresses can avert blackouts . The blackout in August 2003 that struck the northeastern U.S. and parts of Canada was primarily caused by the deregulation of the utility companies . Experts said that changes in the industry had several adverse effects , including loss of experienced personnel and lawyers and MBAs now heading the utility companies rather than engineers . Power plant capacity and Power plant capacity state of repair are proprietary now and not available to system operators who manage regional power grids . An August 2005 federal law provides for mandatory reliability rules , but no power to enforce rules . The factor widely considered behind The blackout in August 2003 that struck the northeastern U.S. and parts of Canada is the deregulation of the electric system . Under a regulated system , utilities could add transmission lines to increase reliability and utilities costs would be reimbursed through the regulatory process . Market participants prefer lower margins to drive up prices . An August 2005 federal law now provides a mechanism for creating mandatory reliability rules . Some firms have identified advances in technology : cheap , powerful chips , more capable software and broadband communications that will impact on the energy business . Power saving devices and developing alternate power sources can contribute to the reliability of the power system . California imposed rolling power cuts in 2001 to deal with strains on the grid . In 2005 Los Angeles suffered three significant electrical failures , due to mistakes by workers or automatic systems . In 2005 the US and Canada discussed the deregulation of the utility companies . Utilities now have little incentive to invest in transmission lines , keep reserve power to minimize shortages , or share information on power plant operating status . Plants operate closer to reliability limits more often . MBAs and lawyers head power companies rather than engineers . Energy company ownership continues to consolidate .

summary: By April 2005 the cause of legalizing gay marriage was making remarkable headway in Europe and Canada , edging slowly ahead in sections of the U.S. and facing aggressive opposition in some other states . Spain , Denmark , Norway , Sweden , Iceland and Finland had legalized gay marriage . In Canada 7 of the 10 provinces and one of three territories accepted gay marriage . In the U.S. eighteen states had passed constitutional amendments prohibiting gay marriage while Massachusetts allows and three New England states , New Jersey , California and Hawaii had taken steps toward allowing gay marriage . Spain joined Belgium and the Netherlands as the only European countries to legalize homosexual marriages . In the U.S. , a judge threw out an amendment to the Louisiana Constitution banning gay marriage . Massachusetts legalized gay marriage in May. Arkansas , Georgia , Kentucky , Michigan , Mississippi , Missouri , Montana , North Dakota , Ohio , Oklahoma , Oregon and Utah have all passed constitutional bans on gay marriage . A US judge ruled that California state law effectively bans gay marriage as unconstitutional . Over half of Canada 10 provinces and tree territories allow same - sex marriage . Homosexual marriages were legalized in Spain including the right to adopt . Some European countries have passed legislation authorizing gay marriages , but not all give gay couples the right to adopt . Poland 's senate approved draft bill allowing same - sex partnerships . In Canada , seven provinces authorized gay marriages . In the U.S. , gay marriages are banned in 18 states . Massachusetts legalized gay marriages and Vermont 's law applies to civil unions . Judges in California and New York ruled state laws banning gay marriages were unconstitutional . the Netherlands and Belgium allow gay marriage . Denmark , Norway , Sweden , Iceland , Finland and France give gay couples the same legal rights as married heterosexual couples . Spain approved a bill to legalize homosexual marriages . Poland 's upper house approved legal partnership rights . Massachusetts allows homosexual marriage . Vermont 's and Connecticut allow civil unions . Judges in Louisiana and California declared state bans on gay marriage unconstitutional . Eighteen states including Arkansas , Georgia , Kansas , Kentucky , Michigan , Mississippi , Missouri , Montana , North Dakota , Ohio , Oklahoma , Oregon , and Utah ban same - sex marriage . Saskatchewan became the seventh Canadian province to allow gay marriage . The Roman Catholic Church opposes gay marriage .

summary: On June 29 , 2005 the Canadian House of Commons passed legislation to legalize gay marriage on a national basis . In Britain a Civil Partnership Act took effect on Dec. 5 , 2005 granting some legal rights and tax benefits to gay couples . By March 2006 homosexual rights advocates were demonstrating in favor of gay marriage in Taipei , Taiwan . In the U.S. a Maryland judge threw out a law banning gay marriage , lawmakers in New Hampshire defeated a proposed constitutional amendment banning gay marriage , and seven states were prepared to vote on such amendments in November . Texas legislators will vote on a constitutional amendment banning same - sex marriage that is not expected to pass . New Hampshire lawmakers defeated a constitutional ban on gay marriage . The issue is under debate in courts in Maryland , California , New Jersey , New York and Washington State . The US government does not recognize same - sex marriage . Massachusetts is the only state to legalize same - sex marriage , although Vermont and Connecticut allow legalized civil unions . Canada passed landmark legislation to legalize gay marriage everywhere in Canada . However , gay marriage is not legal in Sweden and Taiwan . Many countries have legalized civil unions , but not gay marriage . Canada passed legislation authorizing gay marriages and granting same - sex couples legal rights equal to those in traditional unions . In Sweden , civil unions between homosexuals are legal and the government will decide if the law should be changed to include marriage . Under a Civil Partnership Act , homosexual couples will have the same rights as heterosexual couples . Texas legislation to amend the constitution to ban same - sex marriages is being discussed . Homosexual rights activists urged Taiwan to grant homosexual couples the right to marry . Canada and Spain legalized gay marriage and Britain allowed civil partnerships in 2005 . Germany and Switzerland allow registered partnerships . Portugal recognizes de facto couples regardless of sex . Croatia gives gay couples rights equal to de facto heterosexual couples . New Zealand gives gay couples rights equal to married couples . South Africa allows gay couple adoptions . Sweden Lutheran Church approved gay partnership blessing ceremonies . California , New Jersey , Maine and Hawaii recognize limited forms of gay partnership . State bans on gay unions were rejected by a judge in Maryland and blocked by eleven senators in Texas . summary: Three pipeline projects underway to transport natural gas from Asia to Europe are raising political and unspecified environmental concerns . A northern pipeline delivers gas to Germany , France and England . A central one connects Turkey to Romania , Bulgaria and Austria . The southern one supplies Greece and Italy from Turkey . A northern pipeline circumvents the concept of a common European policy with Russia . Russia has a monopoly agreement on gas exported from Kazakhstan produced in Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan . Russia actions are viewed as applying political pressure on neighboring countries . Three pipeline projects underway to transport natural gas from Asia to Europe are expected to begin operating between 2007 and 2010 . Gazprom , the state - controlled Russian gas group and the German company BASF plan a Baltic Sea pipeline to transport Russian gas directly to Europe . a Baltic Sea pipeline to transport Russian gas directly to Europe will be launched in 2010 , three years from the original estimate . a Baltic Sea pipeline to transport Russian gas directly to Europe will make landfall in northern Germany then continue to the Netherlands and across the English Channel . Austria and Bulgaria plan a gas pipeline from Turkey through Romania , Bulgaria and Hungary to Austria . Construction is to begin on a Turkey - Greece pipeline to transport Caspian and Central Asian natural gas to Europe . An underwater pipeline from Greece to Italy is part of plan . Gazprom , the state - controlled Russian gas group will control A northern pipeline . A northern pipeline will bypass Poland , Ukraine and Belarus , who fear being cut off from Russian gas . Gazprom , the state - controlled Russian gas group and the German company BASF will build A northern pipeline . Gerhard Schroeder , criticized for profiting from a project Gerhard Schroeder , criticized for profiting from a project he supported while German chancellor , supported while German chancellor , will chair the board . Gazprom , the state - controlled Russian gas group arranged a monopoly on gas from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan through Kazakhstan . The Austria - Bulgaria & quot;Nabucco&quot ; project is a gas pipeline from Turkey to Austria . A Southern Europe Gas Ring from Turkey through Greece and across the Ionian Sea to Italy is to be completed by 2006 . The Northern European Gas Pipeline , which will bring gas from Northern Siberia through Russia and under the Baltic Sea to northern Germany , then to the Netherlands and under the English Channel to Britain . summary: Russia restored the reduced gas flow through Ukrainian pipelines which had sparked emergencies throughout Europe raising questions about Russia reliability . restored was critically viewed as a foreign policy tool . Ukraine , accused of gas theft , responded that restored was routine . Russia was charged with acts of terror in pipeline explosions in Georgia . Croatia and Hungary are considering an Adriatic Sea pipeline to decrease reliance on Russia . The European Union imports some gas from Russia but parts of Europe are mainly Russia dependent . A proposed trans - Caspian pipeline linking gas directly to the West bypassing Russia is causing renewed conflicts . Gazprom intends to remain the leading gas supplier to Europe and to expand Gazprom markets . However , Russia disruption of gas supplies to Europe during freezing weather raised concerns about Russia ability to ensure steady fuel supplies . Pipelines supplying Russian gas go through Ukraine , accused of gas theft , and each country blames the other for the shortage . Croatia and Hungary are weighing construction of a pipeline from Adriatic Sea to bring Middle Eastern gas to Europe and decrease reliance on Russian gas . Russia has opposed a US - backed pipeline project that would bypass Russia and link Central Asian gas fields directly to the West . Faced with mounting criticism , Russia restored gas withheld from Ukraine , accused of gas theft , in an alleged pricing dispute but suspected to be Russia meddling in Ukraine , accused of gas theft , internal politics . Steady fuel supplies from Gazprom became questioned . Austria proposed a gas pipeline from Iran to Austria as part of Nabucco . Gas pipeline explosions in January 2006 were blamed on both Russia and terrorists . Croatia and Hungary are considering a liquified petroleum gas terminal on the Adriatic coast and a pipeline to Europe to decrease reliance on Russian gas . A US - backed trans - Caspian pipeline is proposed that would bring Central Asian gas to Europe and bypass Russia . Russia restored the flow of natural gas through the Ukrainian pipeline in early January because of a pricing dispute . The resulting European energy crisis made European governments question Russia reliability and seek alternative sources . Austria is weighing the construction of a pipeline from Iran through Turkey and the Balkans . Croatia and Hungary are considering a pipeline to bring liquid gas from North Africa and the Middle East . The U.S.supports a proposed pipeline under Adriatic Sea to bring gas from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan through Azerbaijan , Georgia , and Turkey . Pipeline explosions cut Russia gas supply to Georgia and Armenia .

summary: & quot;Harry Potter and the Half - Blood Prince,&quot ; number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling will go on sale in July 2005 . The publication date will be simultaneous in several countries . Bloomsbury Publishing 's stock surged with the news . More than 5 million pre - orders have been received by booksellers worldwide . 10.8 million copies of the first printing and 635,000 audio book copies will be available in July 2005 . Four separate editions are planned for US and UK audiences . In two separate cases , theft and accidental pre - release sales , injunctions forbidding the leaking of details prior to publication were issued . number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling will go on sale on July 16 in Britain , US , Canada , Australia , New Zealand , South Africa and China . the news delighted readers , booksellers , and owners of Bloomsbury Publishing stock , whose shares surged 7 % . Within 24 hours , number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling shot to Number 1 on Amazon 's bestseller list . British police arrested two men for the theft of two copies of number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling six weeks before number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling launch . Amazon.com had more than 1.2 million pre - orders world - wide and bookstores expected to sell 50,000 copies an hour for the first 24 hours . summary: A Canadian store that sold copies of the book before the launch begged for copies of the book return . An unprecedented court injunction was issued to prevent those purchasers from reading , copying , selling , or talking about the book prior to the launch . In the first 24 hours available , the book sold 6.9 copies in the US . The second printing is being delivered to US bookstores . A Braille edition will be available within 3 days of the launch so the sight impaired will not have to wait . The Potter books have been translated into 63 languages with more than 300 million copies sold . Special events were planned at bookstores worldwide , including Asia , for the launch . The author herself was to host a special celebration at Edinburgh Castle for 70 children from around the world . A US drug store accidentally sold one copy of the book ahead of the launch . The customer agreed to return one copy of the book . the book shattered publishing records in the US . A Braille edition of the book is was released on July 19 . In October , French , Portuguese and Chinese editions of the book were released . The publisher offered signed editions and gift packs to customers of a Canadian supermarket and US drug store who accidentally bought books early . A judge ordered Canadians not to read the book until the launch . A Braille edition came out three days after the launch . French , Portuguese and Chinese translations came out in October . 70 children from around the world were to write articles after being granted The publisher only press conference . the book shattered US records , selling 6.9 million copies in the first day . The second printing hit stores immediately . Pre - orders were double those for book five . Several copies of the book were sold accidentally before 16 October , one in a New York drug store and 14 in a Canadian grocery store . A Canadian judge ordered Several copies of the sixth Harry Potter book not to even read the book until the launch . The sale of more than 6.9.million copies in the first 24 hours in the US broke all records . The second printing was already on bookshelves . A Braille edition was released three days after publication . The French translation was released on 1 October ; the Portuguese , on 14 October ; and the Chinese , in mid - October .

summary: President Bush 's nomination of Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court caused much consternation . Harriet Miers was endorsed by the Democratic Senate leader while the Republican conservative base was splintered . Moderate Republicans sided with President Bush 's while most Democrats and liberal advocacy groups stayed out of the fray . On Oct. 12 , 2005 President Bush 's tried to promote confirmation by vouching for Harriet Miers as an evangelical Christian , but conservatives said the issue was not religion but Harriet Miers lack of qualifications . On Oct. 21 the Senate Judiciary Committee found Harriet Miers answers to a committee questionnaire & quot;inadequate,&quot ; & quot;insufficient,&quot ; and & quot;insulting.&quot ; President Bush 's nominated President Bush 's longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court to replace retiring Justice Sandra Day O'Conner . Miers , currently White House counsel , would join Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg as the second woman on the Supreme Court . Conservatives urged President Bush 's to withdraw nominated saying that Harriet Miers lacks the qualifications having never been a judge and has little experience in constitutional law . Conservatives further state that nominated looks like cronyism . There is also concern that Harriet Miers religious belief may influence Harriet Miers decisions as a Justice . President Bush 's nominated President Bush 's longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court . The announcement initially drew kind words from some Democrats but skepticism from some conservatives . Some President Bush 's critics charged cronyism in nominated . Harriet Miers has few credentials of any kind to carry Harriet Miers into confirmation hearings and little experience in constitutional law . the Senate Judiciary Committee called Harriet Miers response to a committee questionnaire inadequate , insufficient and insulting . President Bush 's stated that part of Harriet Miers life is her religious belief and stated appeared to further inflame the controversy . Conservatives continued to deride nominated and called for nominated withdrawal . President Bush 's has nominated Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court . nominated must be confirmed by Senate . There is increasingly strong opposition to nominated , with outrage expressed by conservatives such as Pat Buchanan and Charles Krauthammer . The major objections are that Harriet Miers has few credentials or qualifications and that nominated looks like cronyism . President Bush 's cited religion as one criterion for nominated . Harriet Miers is scheduled to face the Senate Judiciary Committee in November . the Senate Judiciary Committee sent Harriet Miers a questionaire , but found her response to a questionnaire & quot;inadequate&quot ; and & quot;insulting&quot ; and asked Harriet Miers to redo her response to a questionnaire .
