summary: On Oct. 27 , 2005 , a little more than three weeks after offering the nomination of Harriet Miers , President Bush announced that Harriet Miers had withdrawn the nomination of Harriet Miers . Many expressed sympathy for how Harriet Miers had been treated . Republicans , including Harriet Miers , blamed failure of the nomination of Harriet Miers on the Senate Judiciary Committee 's demands for documents from the White House , but the committee chair denied intruding on executive privilege . Democrats blamed failure of the nomination on right - wing ideologues . Sen. Lott ( R - MS ) blamed failure of the nomination on a nomination based on cronyism . On Oct. 28 President Bush said President Bush would quickly select another candidate . Harriet Miers withdrawn the nomination of Harriet Miers from consideration as a Supreme Court justice . Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee 's questioned Harriet Miers conservative credentials , lack of judicial experience and criticized Harriet Miers for not completely answering a questionnaire about Harriet Miers work at the White House . Others said the White House bungled the nomination of Harriet Miers from the start . Many agreed that although Harriet Miers is a very capable person , President Bush should n't have chosen someone not qualified to serve on Supreme Court . President Bush announced that Harriet Miers had withdrawn the nomination of Harriet Miers . announced was met with a blend of regret , relief and a feeling that Harriet Miers had been treated poorly . Harriet Miers said withdrawn was to avoid burdening the White House over access to documents on advice Harriet Miers gave President Bush since lawmakers had requested documents on advice she gave Bush . Some senators said that Harriet Miers had been the victim of bad handling and the White House had capitulated to the far right wing of the Republican Party . Right Wing partisans expressed relief and some jubilation at withdrawn . Harriet Miers withdrawn the nomination of Harriet Miers three and a half weeks after announced . President Bush declared on 27 October that President Bush choice had withdrawn Harriet Miers name and that President Bush had & quot;reluctantly accepted&quot ; withdrawn . Harriet Miers claimed that the fight over the nomination of Harriet Miers would be a burden for the White House . Harriet Miers also said that Harriet Miers wanted to protect the independence of the executive branch , citing the battle over access to Harriet Miers the White House legal writings . Harriet Miers will continue to serve as the White House counsel . President Bush promised to name a replacement & quot;in a timely manner.&quot ;

summary: In July 2005 ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson , submitted a paper questioning the sufficiency of the evidence for the ivory - billed woodpecker 's rediscovery . ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson withdrew a paper questioning the sufficiency of the evidence for the ivory - billed woodpecker 's rediscovery after hearing audio recordings of calls and raps reportedly matching 1930 's recordings of the ivory - billed woodpecker 's . But ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson and others remained skeptical . In December over 100 researchers and volunteers began an intensive six - month search across 500,000 acres of Arkansas wetlands seeking definitive evidence of the ivory - billed woodpecker 's . A local town benefited from bird watching tourists . In January 2006 Jerome Jackson published an article saying claims for proof of the ivory - billed woodpecker 's existence constitute & quot;faith - based ornithology&quot ; . Biologists question evidence in sightings of the ivory - billed woodpecker 's . The issue is whether four seconds of fuzzy videotape is an ivory - billed or pileated woodpecker . Recordings of the ivory - billed woodpecker 's distinctive double - rap sounds convinced scientists of the bird 's existence . A crew from Cornell Lab and Cornell Lab partner agencies will train 100 volunteers for a six - month search of 500,000 acres in the eastern Arkansas wetlands . An the ivory - billed woodpecker 's specialist criticized convinced saying the bird 's existence has n't been confirmed and four seconds of fuzzy videotape shows a pileated woodpecker . ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson questioned reported sightings and four seconds of fuzzy videotape as sufficient evidence that the ivory - billed woodpecker 's is not extinct . However , more recent audio recordings of calls and distinctive double - rap sounds removed ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson doubts . Cornell Lab ornithologists made 17,000 hours of recordings near the Cache and White rivers in Arkansas . convinced raised concerns that this habitat could be inundated with bird watchers . Cornell Lab will train 100 volunteers for a six - month search for the ivory - billed woodpecker 's . Federal authorities have provided $ 10.2 M toward the effort and the Nature Conservancy has bought 18,000 acres of Big Woods habitat to set aside for the ivory - billed woodpecker 's . the ivory - billed woodpecker 's rediscovery was challenged in late April , almost three months after the ivory - billed woodpecker 's rediscovery announcement . ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson planned to publish a paper saying that the evidence was insufficient , a conclusion also reached by Sibley , author of well - known field guides . But two of ornithologists Richard Prum , Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson were given recordings based on 18,000 hours of audio and , on the basis of this & quot;new evidence,&quot ; two of the scientists withdrew two of the scientists challenge and the paper was not published . In January 2006 , however , the third biologist voiced the strongest criticism to date , saying that the third biologist was still not convinced . The search continues .

summary: Pope John Paul II , 84 , died in Rome on April 2 , 2005 from Parkinson 's disease . Sunday Pope John Paul II , 84 , body lay in state at the Vatican 's Apostolic Palace . St. Peter 's Basilica was closed to the public to prepare for the funeral and interment on Friday . Major security measures including a no - fly zone and marksmen are being undertaken to protect the 200 state leaders attending . Condolences and mourners from around the world are arriving in Rome . A tent city has been erected as a camp for mourners . Millions more are mourning worldwide . The College of Cardinals is beginning preparations to select a successor . Following died , mourners gathered worldwide . Chinese Catholic Bishops sent condolences to the Vatican 's . Philippine Catholics express deep grief as church bells tolled . Over 500,000 people signed an online condolence book . On April 3 , his body lay in state in the Vatican 's Apostolic Palace . Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims arrived from Europe and around the world to pay Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims respects . Some 800,000 gathered in Krakow , Poland for a memorial mass . Hundreds of dignitaries , leaders and heads of state from around the world headed to Rome for the funeral . Pope John Paul II , 84 , died after a long battle with Parkinson 's disease . his body was displayed at the Vatican 's Apostolic Palace and on the Vatican 's television and will be interred in the crypt of St. Peter 's Basilica . A vast security operation went into effect as dignitaries and over a million pilgrims from around the world arrived paying dignitaries and over a million pilgrims from around the world last respects . Near Krakow , Poland , 800,000 people gathered for a mass in memory of Pope John Paul II , 84 , . More than half a million people have & quot;signed&quot ; a condolence book in cyberspace . Pope John Paul II , 84 , died on Saturday night , 2 April , after a long battle with Parkinson 's disease . Pope John Paul II , 84 , had had acute breathing problems for two months and had suffered a heart attack two days before died . his body was displayed at the Vatican 's Apostolic Palace on Sunday . the funeral is to be held on Friday . Two hundred world leaders are expected to attend , creating an enormous security problem . Meanwhile more than a million pilgrims have been gathering to pay more than a million pilgrims respects . his body are to be interred in the crypt of Saint Peter 's Basilica .

summary: The funeral service for Pope John Paul II was held Friday , April 8 . Mourners interrupted The funeral service for Pope John Paul II by calling for sainthood for Pope John Paul II now . Friday , April 8 was declared a national day of mourning in Poland , home of Pope John Paul II birth , and in Malawi , South Africa . In Krakow live images of The funeral service for Pope John Paul II were telecast from Rome . Monuments will be erected throughout Poland , home of his birth to honor Pope John Paul II . One monument was inaugurated immediately on Saturday in the Rakowicki cemetery , Krakow where members of Pope John Paul II family are buried . Cardinals will begin the conclave to elect a successor on April 18 . The world said a final farewell to Pope John Paul II at Pope John Paul II solemn funeral on Friday , April 8 . A huge throng of mourners applauded as Pope John Paul II coffin was carried from Saint Peter 's Basilica and placed before the altar . Dignitaries stood in respect . The funeral service for Pope John Paul II followed centuries of solemn ritual . Pope John Paul II was interred in the crypt of Saint Peter 's Basilica . Poland , home of his birth declared a national holiday . Hundreds of thousands of mourners gathered to watch The funeral service for Pope John Paul II . Hundreds gathered for interfaith prayers at a Warsaw synagogue . Cardinals will meet on April 18 to elect a new pontiff . The funeral service for Pope John Paul II began in Saint Peter 's Square in front of a huge throng of mourners including state leaders who applauded as his coffin was placed on the altar . In Tokyo , Japan , diplomats and government officials joined 1,500 Catholics in a mass mourning for Pope John Paul II . Several hundred people of all faiths prayed at a Warsaw synagogue . The Grand Rabbi of Poland , home of his birth led the ecumenical prayer . A monument to Pope John Paul II was inaugurated in a Krakow cemetery , where his family is buried . The funeral service for Pope John Paul II was held for Pope John Paul II in Saint Peter 's Square from 10am-12:30 pm on Friday , April 8 . As The funeral service for Pope John Paul II ended , lengthy applause broke out from A huge throng of mourners . The body , in a plain cypress wooden coffin , was laid to rest in the crypt of Saint Peter 's Basilica following The funeral service for Pope John Paul II . On Saturday a monument was unveiled at the Krakow cemetary where his family is buried . The cardinals will meet in secret to elect a successor .

summary: Prior to parliamentary elections on Feb. 27 , 2005 about 300 opposition activists gathered in Kyrgyzstan 's capital Bishkek demonstrating in favor of democratic elections and calling for President Askar Akayev to step down at the end of President Askar Akayev second term in October . The administration staged a counter - demonstration . After President Askar Akayev won overwhelming election victories the opposition charged the government with mass election violations , blocked roads , occupied government buildings , and held a regional governor and a district chief hostage . President Askar Akayev ordered investigation and negotiations and fired the interior minister and prosecutor general while police dispersed crowds in Kyrgyzstan 's capital Bishkek . In February 2005 rallies in Kyrgyzstan 's capital Bishkek urged President Askar Akayev to step down as promised and constitutionally required after October presidential elections , fearing a referendum to continue President Askar Akayev reign . President Askar Akayev supporters won a landslide parliamentary victory . Opposition leaders and the European Organization for Security and Cooperation charged October presidential elections were flawed . By March 16 opposition forces rallied , blocked roads , occupied government buildings , demanded President Askar Akayev resignation , and took hostage a regional governor and a district chief . On March 20 four policemen were beaten after police fired shots at demonstrators . President Askar Akayev ordered investigations into election fraud charges and fired the interior minister and prosecutor general . Kyrgyz oppositionists , fearing President Askar Akayev might hold onto power longer than President Askar Akayev constitutional two terms , rallied and urged President Askar Akayev to step down . President Askar Akayev refused , saying elections were fair , opposition leaders were unnecessarily inciting civil war , and talks were the solution to the crisis . the opposition refused to accept a landslide parliamentary victory and claimed fraud . the opposition blocked roads , occupied government buildings , and took a regional governor and a district chief hostage . When police fired shots to dispel rioters , crowds beat four policemen to death . President Askar Akayev ordered fraud claims investigated and replaced the interior minister and prosecutor general . parliamentary elections on Feb. 27 , 2005 were held in Kyrgyzstan 's on 27 February , with October presidential elections planned for October . Akayev supporters won a landslide victory in most areas , but both opposition leaders and western observers cited mass violations . Run - off parliamentary elections were held in many regions on 13 March . the opposition was defeated but refused to accept the results and demanded Akayev 's resignation . Even before parliamentary elections on Feb. 27 , 2005 , opposition leaders had been calling for President Askar Akayev to step down as President at the end of October in accordance with the constitution . But President Askar Akayev refused to resign or to annul the results .

summary: On March 24 , 2005 mass protests outside the presidential compound in Bishkek turned violent . Demonstrators broke into the presidential compound in Bishkek and beat several officials severely . Akayev fled the country for Russia and soon announced in Moscow that Akayev would resign if the country would guarantee Akayev safety . On April 3 a Kyrgyzstan parliamentary delegation arrived in Moscow and after 3 hours of talks Akayev signed a resignation document . Akayev also taped an 18 - minute farewell address to be played in Bishkek while Akayev remained in Moscow . New presidential elections are scheduled for June 26 . On March 24 , 2005 protestors stormed the presidential compound in Bishkek and Akayev fled to Russia . The elected pro - Akayev parliament nonetheless elected an Akayev opponent as Speaker and called for new presidential elections on June 26 . On April 3 , Akayev signed Akayev resignation in Moscow , which was notarized in lieu of a constitutional requirement that Akayev present his resignation in person to The elected pro - Akayev parliament . Because Akayev safety still could not be guaranteed , due to continued calls for Akayev impeachment , an 18 - minute farewell address to be played in Bishkek while he remained in Moscow was to be heard and accepted by a special session of The elected pro - Akayev parliament on April 6 and broadcast live . Opposition against Akayev strengthened with international criticism for election abuses , the country crackdown on opposition groups and independent media , and Akayev failure to bring those responsible for killing six peaceful demonstrators in 2002 to justice . Poverty and widespread corruption contributed to public anger . Akayev fled to Russia after opposition supporters stormed the presidential compound in Bishkek and mobs looted parts of Bishkek . Akayev his resignation as president in Moscow , with impeachment the alternative . In Akayev address to the country , Akayev apologized to people who bore Akayev grudges , hoped the presidential election would be democratic , and said Akayev would n't fight the new government . Massive uprisings continued in the country , fueled by anger over the rigged parliamentary elections . When protesters finally stormed the presidential compound in Bishkek on 30 March , Akayev fled to Moscow . Two nights of looting and gunfire followed in Bishkek . a Kyrgyzstan parliamentary delegation went to Moscow to negotiate with Akayev . Akayev signed his resignation at the Kyrgyz Embassy in Moscow on 4 April . an 18 - minute farewell address to be played in Bishkek while he remained in Moscow was to be shown to The elected pro - Akayev parliament and then broadcast on national television . Presidential elections are now scheduled for June 26 .

summary: Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk was indicted for insulting the Turkish identity by comments Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk made to a Swiss reporter about one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk could face up to three years in prison . The US and EU called on Turkey to drop the charges . Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk December 16 trial was suspended until February 7 because the court lacked a justice ministry order to proceed . The case has stirred outrage across Europe . EU officials were there to observe His December 16 trial . Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk , was indicted over comments he made to a Swiss reporter about one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. . Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk is charged under Turkey penal code which carries a jail term of more than three years for a person who & quot;explicitly insults&quot ; Turkey . EU warned Turkey that indicted could damage Turkey chance of joining EU and is a test of Turkey commitment to freedom of expression and reforms in Turkey law . European countries , U.S. and activist organizations have criticized Turkey lack of democratic principles and citizen 's rights . In a Swiss interview , Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk said Turkey deliberately massacred one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. during WWI , triggering public outrage . Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk was indicted under Turkey revised penal code for & quot;public denigration of the Turkish identity,&quot ; carrying up to 3 years in jail . Turkey says one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. were fewer and from civil unrest , not genocide . The US , European Union , and activist organizations criticized the charges . EU said His December 16 trial would affect Turkey EU bid . A Turkish court ruled Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk should be tried under old laws requiring justice ministry direct order and postponed His December 16 trial . Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk went to the court on December 16 for comments he made to a Swiss reporter about one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. . EU warned that His December 16 trial could affect Turkey EU accession process because His December 16 trial would indicate the strength of Turkey commitment to recent reforms guaranteeing freedom of expression . The EU Enlargement Commissioner said , & quot;It is not Prominent award - winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk who will stand trial , but Turkey.&quot ; His December 16 trial was suspended until 7 February pending a decision from justice ministry . The offense had been made before the new penal code had gone into effect and therefore came under its law .

summary: Turkey was heavily criticized by international human rights groups over Orhan Pamuk 's trial . Turkish intellectuals and EU officials demanded that Turkey change the laws that limit freedom of expression . To avoid an EU confrontation , Turkey justice minister sent Orhan Pamuk 's case back to the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality . EU welcomed sent . Turkey categorically denies Armenian accusations that up to 1.5 million died in a genocide orchestrated by the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1917 . A group of 169 Turkish intellectuals asked Turkey to scrap laws that limit freedom of expression and interfere with Turkey democratic process . the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality dropped charges against Orhan Pamuk 's stating that the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality was n't legally competent to judge Pamuk 's case . the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality was chided for framing dropped in bureaucratic terms rather than addressing freedom of expression . About 70 intellectuals have been charged as well , but About 70 intellectuals do n't have the same high profile as Orhan Pamuk 's . EU pressed Turkey to address legal loopholes limiting freedom of speech in other cases . Turkey 's justice minister declined to rule on whether Orhan Pamuk 's should be tried , citing recent penal code amendments . Turkey 's justice minister sent Pamuk 's case back to the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality . Pamuk 's case divided Turkey and embarrassed Turkey liberals . Orhan Pamuk 's remarks also highlighted another painful episode in Turkish history , the 30,000 Kurdish deaths in recent guerrilla fighting in Turkey Kurdish southeast . Turkish intellectuals , EU , and most of the West called on Turkey to scrap laws limiting freedom of expression . Potential EU partners wanted to know that Turkish laws were the same as laws elsewhere in EU . Pamuk 's case ended on 23 January . Turkey 's justice minister had refused to issue an approval of the prosecution and told the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality that the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality should determine whether to proceed . the local Istanbul court , which then dropped the charges on a technicality dropped the charges . Orhan Pamuk 's lawyer criticized dropped , saying that dropped was framed in bureaucratic terms and avoided the issue of freedom of expression . Turkish nationalists were outraged . The EU Enlargement Commissioner said that Orhan Pamuk 's was not the only one facing such charges , Orhan Pamuk 's was & quot;just the most high - profile case.&quot ; PEN says that some 70 Turkish intellectuals have been charged with similar offenses .
